greek: πρὸς τοὺς ἐπὶ τῷ ἐλεεῖσθαι ὀδυνωμένους. ἀνιῶμαι, φησίν, ἐλεούμενος. — πότερον οὖν σὸν ἔργον ἐστὶ τὸ ἐλεεῖσθαί σε ἢ τῶν ἐλεούντων; τί δʼ; ἐπὶ σοί ἐστι τὸ παῦσαι αὐτό; — ἐπʼ ἐμοί, ἂν δεικνύω αὐτοῖς μῆ ἄξιον ἐλέου ὄντα ἐμαυτόν. — πότερον δʼ ἤδη σοι ὑπάρχει τοῦτο, τὸ μὴ εἶναι ἐλέου ἄξιον ἢ οὐχ ὑπάρχει; — δοκῶ ἔγωγε, ὅτι ὑπάρχει. ἀλλʼ οὗτοί γʼ οὐκ ἐπὶ τούτοις ἐλεοῦσιν, ἐφʼ οἷς, εἴπερ ἄρα, ἦν ἄξιον, ἐπὶ τοῖς ἁμαρτανομένοις, ἀλλʼ ἐπὶ πενίᾳ καὶ ἀναρχίᾳ καὶ νόσοις καὶ θανάτοις καὶ ἄλλοις τοιούτοις. — πότερον οὖν πείθειν παρεσκεύασαι τοὺς πολλούς, ὡς ἄρα οὐδὲν τούτων κακόν ἐστιν, ἀλλʼ οἷόν τε καὶ πένητι καὶ ἄρχοντι τούτων γὰρ τὰ μὲν δεύτερα ἀλαζόνος καὶ ψυχροῦ καὶ οὐδενὸς ἀξίου. καὶ ἡ προσποίησις ὅρα διʼ οἵων ἂν γένοιτο· δουλάριά σε χρήσασθαι δεήσει καὶ ἀργυρωμάτια ὀλίγα κεκτῆσθαι καὶ ταῦτα ἐν φανερῷ δεικνύειν, εἰ οἷόν τε, ταὐτὰ πολλάκις καὶ λανθάνειν πειρᾶσθαι ὅτι ταὐτά ἐστιν, καὶ ἱματίδια στιλπνὰ καὶ τὴν ἄλλην πομπὴν καὶ τὸν τιμώμενον ἐπιφαίνειν ὑπὸ τῶν ἐπιφανῶν τούτων καὶ δειπνεῖν πειρᾶσθαι παρʼ αὐτοῖς ἢ δοκεῖν γε, ὅτι δειπνεῖς, καὶ περὶ τὸ σῶμα δέ τινα κακοτεχνεῖν, ὡς εὐμορφότερον φαίνεσθαι καὶ γενναιότερον τοῦ ὄντος· ταῦτά σε δεῖ μηχανᾶσθαι, εἰ τὴν δευτέραν ὁδὸν ἀπιέναι θέλεις ὥστε μὴ ἐλεεῖσθαι. ἡ πρώτη δὲ καὶ ἀνήνυτος καὶ μακρά, ὃ ὁ Ζεὺς οὐκ ἠδυνήθη ποιῆσαι, τοῦτο αὐτὸ ἐπιχειρεῖν, πάντας ἀνθρώπους πεῖσαι, τίνα ἐστὶν ἀγαθὰ καὶ κακά. μὴ γὰρ δέδοταί σοι τοῦτο; ἐκεῖνο μόνον σοι δέδοται, σαυτὸν πεῖσαι. καὶ οὔπω πέπεικας· εἶτά μοι νῦν ἐπιχειρεῖς πείθειν τοὺς ἄλλους; καὶ τίς σοι τοσούτῳ χρόνῳ σύνεστιν ὡς σὺ σαυτῷ; τίς δὲ οὕτως πιθανός ἐστί σοι πρὸς τὸ πεῖσαι ὡς σὺ σαυτῷ; τίς δʼ εὐνούστερον καὶ οἰκειότερον ἔχων ἢ σὺ σαυτῷ; πῶς οὖν οὔπω πέπεικας σαυτὸν μαθεῖν; νῦν οὐχὶ ἄνω κάτω; τοῦτʼ ἔστι περὶ ὃ ἐσπούδακας; οὐ μανθάνειν, ὥστε ἄλυπος εἶναι καὶ ἀτάραχος καὶ ἀταπείνωτος καὶ ἐλεύθερος; πρὸς ταῦτα οὖν οὐκ ἀκήκοας, ὅτι μία ἐστὶν ἡ ὁδὸς ἡ φέρουσα, ἀφεῖναι τὰ ἀπροαίρετα καὶ ἐκστῆναι αὐτῶν καὶ ὁμολογῆσαι αὐτὰ ἀλλότρια; τὸ οὖν ἄλλον τι ὑπολαβεῖν περὶ σοῦ ποίου εἴδους ἐστίν; — τοῦ ἀπροαιρέτου. — οὐκοῦν οὐδὲν πρὸς σέ; — οὐδέν. — ἔτι οὖν δακνόμενος ἐπὶ τούτῳ καὶ ταρασσόμενος οἴει πεπεῖσθαι περὶ ἀγαθῶν καὶ κακῶν; οὐ θέλεις οὖν ἀφεὶς τοὺς ἄλλους αὐτὸς σαυτῷ γενέσθαι καὶ μαθητὴς καὶ διδάσκαλος; ὄψονται οἱ ἄλλοι, εἰ λυσιτελεῖ αὐτοῖς παρὰ φύσιν ἔχειν καὶ διεξάγειν, ἐμοὶ δʼ οὐδείς ἐστιν ἐγγίων ἐμοῦ. τί οὖν τοῦτό ἐστιν, ὅτι τοὺς μὲν λόγους ἀκήκοα τοὺς τῶν φιλοσόφων καὶ συγκατατίθεμαι αὐτοῖς, ἔργῳ δʼ οὐδὲν γέγονα κουφότερος; μή τι οὕτως ἀφυής εἰμι; καὶ μὴν περὶ τὰ ἄλλα, ὅσα ἐβουλήθην, οὐ λίαν ἀφυὴς εὑρέθην, ἀλλὰ καὶ γράμματα ταχέως ἔμαθον καὶ παλαίειν καὶ γεωμετρεῖν καὶ συλλογισμοὺς ἀναλύειν. μή τι οὖν οὐ πέπεικέ με ὁ λόγος; καὶ μὴν οὐκ ἄλλα τινὰ οὕτως ἐξ ἀρχῆς ἐδοκίμασα ἣ εἱλόμην καὶ νῦν περὶ τούτων ἀναγιγνώσκω, ταῦτα ἀκούω, ταῦτα γράφω· ἄλλον οὐχ εὑρήκαμεν μέχρι νῦν ἰσχυρότερον τούτου λόγον. τί οὖν τὸ λεῖπόν μοι ἐστίν; μὴ οὐκ ἐξῄρηται τἀναντία δόγματα; μὴ αὐταὶ αἱ ὑπολήψεις ἀγύμναστοί εἰσιν οὐδʼ εἰθισμέναι ἀπαντᾶν ἐπὶ τὰ ἔργα, ἀλλʼ ὡς ὁπλάρια ἀποκείμενα κατίωται καὶ οὐδὲ περιαρμόσαι μοι δύναται; καίτοι οὔτʼ ἐπὶ τοῦ παλαίειν οὔτʼ ἐπὶ τοῦ γράφειν ἢ ἀναγιγνώσκειν ἀρκοῦμαι τῷ μαθεῖν, ἀλλʼ ἄνω κάτω στρέφω τοὺς προτεινομένους καὶ ἄλλους πλέκω καὶ μεταπίπτοντας ὡσαύτως. τὰ δʼ ἀναγκαῖα θεωρήματα, ἀφʼ ὧν ἔστιν ὁρμώμενον ἄλυπον γενέσθαι, ἄφοβον ἀπαθῆ, ἀκώλυτον, ἐλεύθερον, ταῦτα δʼ οὐ γυμνάζω οὐδὲ μελετῶ κατὰ ταῦτα τὴν προσήκουσαν μελέτην. εἶτά μοι μέλει, τί οἱ ἄλλοι περὶ ἐμοῦ ἐροῦσιν, εἰ φανοῦμαι αὐτοῖς ἀξιόλογος, εἰ φανοῦμαι εὐδαίμων; ταλαίπωρε, οὐ θέλεις βλέπειν, τί σὺ λέγεις περὶ σαυτοῦ; τίς φαίνῃ σαυτῷ; τίς ἐν τῷ ὑπολαμβάνειν, τίς ἐν τῷ ὀρέγεσθαι, τίς ἐν τῷ ἐκκλίνειν· τίς ἐν ὁρμῇ, παρασκευῇ, ἐπιβολῇ, τοῖς ἄλλοις τοῖς ἀνθρωπικοῖς ἔργοις; ἀλλὰ μέλει σοι, εἴ σε ἐλεοῦσιν οἱ ἄλλοι; — ναί· ἀλλὰ παρὰ τὴν ἀξίαν ἐλεοῦμαι. — οὐκοῦν ἐπὶ τούτῳ ὀδυνᾷ; ὁ δέ γε ὀδυνώμενος ἐλεεινός ἐστιν; — ναί. — πῶς οὖν ἔτι παρὰ ἀξίαν ἐλεῇ; αὐτοῖς γὰρ οἷς περὶ τὸν ἔλεον πάσχεις κατασκευάζεις σεαυτὸν ἄξιον τοῦ ἐλεεῖσθαι. τί οὖν λέγει Ἀντισθένης; οὐδέποτʼ ἤκουσας; βασιλικόν, ὦ Κῦρε, πράττειν μὲν εὖ, κακῶς δʼ ἀκούειν. τὴν κεφαλὴν ὑγιᾶ ἔχω καὶ πάντες οἴονται ὅτι κεφαλαλγῶ. τί μοι μέλει; ἀπύρετός εἰμι καὶ ὡς πυρέσσοντί μοι συνάχθονται· τάλας, ἐκ τοσούτου χρόνου οὐ διέλειπες πυρέσσων. ναί· ταῖς ἀληθείαις πολὺς ἤδη χρόνος, ἐξ οὗ μοι κακῶς ἐστιν. τί οὖν γένηται; τί οὖν κωλύει καὶ ἐνταῦθα ὁμοίως; πένης εἰμί, ἀλλὰ ὀρθὸν δόγμα ἔχω περὶ πενίας. τί οὖν μοι μέλει, εἴ μʼ ἐπὶ τῇ πενίᾳ ἐλεοῦσιν; οὐκ ἄρχω, ἄλλοι δʼ ἄρχουσιν. ἀλλʼ ὃ δεῖ ὑπειληφέναι, ὑπείληφα περὶ τοῦ ἄρχειν καὶ μὴ ἄρχειν. ὄψονται οἱ ἐλεοῦντές με, ἐγὼ δʼ οὔτε πεινῶ οὔτε διψῶ οὔτε ῥιγῶ, ἀλλʼ ἀφʼ ὧν αὐτοὶ πεινῶσιν ἢ διψῶσιν οἴονται κἀμέ. τί οὖν αὐτοῖς ποιήσω; περιερχόμενος κηρύσσω καὶ λέγω μὴ πλανᾶσθε, ἄνδρες, ἐμοὶ καλῶς ἐστιν· οὔτε πενίας ἐπιστρέφομαι οὔτε ἀναρχίας οὔτε ἁπλῶς ἄλλου οὐδενὸς ἢ δογμάτων ὀρθῶν· ταῦτα ἔχω ἀκώλυτα, οὐδενὸς πεφρόντικα ἔτι; καὶ τίς αὕτη φλυαρία; πῶς ἔτι ὀρθὰ δόγματα ἔχω μὴ ἀρκούμενος τῷ εἶναι ὅς εἰμι, ἀλλʼ ἐπτοημένος ὑπὲρ τοῦ δοκεῖν; ἀλλʼ ἄλλοι πλειόνων τεύξονται καὶ προτιμηθήσονται. — τί οὖν εὐλογώτερον ἢ τοὺς περί τι ἐσπουδακότας ἐν ἐκείνῳ πλεῖον ἔχειν, ἐν ᾧ ἐσπουδάκασιν; περὶ ἀρχὰς ἐσπουδάκασιν, σὺ περὶ δόγματα· καὶ περὶ πλοῦτον, σὺ περὶ τὴν χρῆσιν τῶν φαντασιῶν. ὅρα, εἰ ἐν τούτῳ σου πλέον ἔχουσιν, περὶ ὃ σὺ μὲν ἐσπούδακας, ἐκεῖνοι δʼ ἀμελοῦσιν· εἰ συγκατατίθενται μᾶλλον περὶ τὰ φυσικὰ μέτρα, εἰ ὀρέγονταί σου ἀναποτευκτότερον, εἰ ἐκκλίνουσιν ἀπεριπτωτότερον, εἰ ἐν ἐπιβολῇ, ἐν προθέσει, εἰ ἐν ὁρμῇ μᾶλλον εὐστοχοῦσιν, εἰ τὸ πρέπον σῴζουσιν ὡς ἄνδρες, ὡς υἱοί, ὡς γονεῖς, εἶθʼ ἑξῆς κατὰ τὰ ἄλλα τῶν σχέσεων ὀνόματα. εἰ δʼ ἄρχουσιν ἐκεῖνοι, σὺ δʼ οὐ θέλεις σαυτῷ τὰς ἀληθείας εἰπεῖν, ὅτι σὺ μὲν οὐδὲν τούτου ἕνεκα ποιεῖς, ἐκεῖνοι δὲ πάντα, ἀλογώτατον δὲ τὸν ἐπιμελούμενόν τινος ἔλαττον φέρεσθαι οὐ οὔ, ἄφες οὖν τὴν περὶ τὰ δόγματα σπουδὴν καὶ περὶ ἐκεῖνα ἀναστρέφου, ἃ κτήσασθαι θέλεις, καὶ τότε κλαῖε, ἐάν σοι μὴ προχωρῇ· κλαίειν γὰρ ἄξιος εἶ. νῦν δὲ πρὸς ἄλλοις γίνεσθαι λέγεις, ἄλλων ἐπιμελεῖσθαι, οἱ πολλοὶ δὲ τοῦτο καλῶς λέγουσιν, ὅτι ἔργον ἔργῳ οὐ κοινωνεῖ. ὁ μὲν ἐξ ὄρθρου ἀναστὰς ζητεῖ, τίνα ἐξ οἴκου ἀσπάσηται, τίνι κεχαρισμένον λόγον εἴπῃ, τίνι δῶρον πέμψῃ, πῶς τῷ ὀρχηστῇ ἀρέσῃ, πῶς κακοηθισάμενος ἄλλον ἄλλῳ χαρίσηται. ὅταν εὔχηται, περὶ τούτων εὔχεται· ὅταν θύῃ, ἐπὶ τούτοις θύει· τὸ τοῦ Πυθαγόρου πῇ παρέβην; τί ἔρεξα; τί γάρ σοι καὶ τοῦτο εἰπεῖν; οὐ γὰρ ἐνῆν ψεύσασθαι; λέγουσιν καὶ οἱ φιλόσοφοι, ὅτι οὐδὲν κωλύει ψεῦδος εἰπεῖν. σὺ δʼ εἴπερ ταῖς ἀληθείαις οὐδενὸς ἄλλου πεφρόντικας ἢ χρήσεως οἵας δεῖ φαντασιῶν, εὐθὺς ἀναστὰς ἕωθεν ἐνθυμοῦ τίνα μοι λείπει πρὸς ἀπάθειαν; τίνα πρὸς ἀταραξίαν; τίς εἰμι; μή τι σωμάτιον, μή τι κτῆσις, μή τι φήμη; οὐδὲν τούτων. ἀλλὰ τί; λογικόν εἰμι ζῷον. τίνα οὖν τὰ ἀπαιτήματα; ἀναπόλει τὰ πεπραγμένα. πῇ παρέβην τῶν πρὸς εὔροιαν; τί ἔρεξα ἢ ἄφιλον ἢ ἀκοινώνητον ἢ ἄγνωμον; τί μοι δέον οὐκ ἐτελέσθη πρὸς ταῦτα; τοσαύτης οὖν διαφορᾶς οὔσης τῶν ἐπιθυμουμένων, τῶν ἔργων, τῶν εὐχῶν ἔτι θέλεις τὸ ἴσον ἔχειν ἐκείνοις, περὶ ἃ σὺ μὲν οὐκ ἐσπούδακας, ἐκεῖνοι δʼ ἐσπουδάκασιν; εἶτα θαυμάζεις, εἴ σʼ ἐλεοῦσιν, καὶ ἀγανακτεῖς; ἐκεῖνοι δʼ οὐκ ἀγανακτοῦσιν, εἰ σὺ αὐτοὺς ἐλεεῖς. διὰ τί; ὅτι ἐκεῖνοι μὲν πεπεισμένοι εἰσίν, ὅτι ἀγαθῶν τυγχάνουσιν, σὺ δʼ οὐ πέπεισαι. διὰ τοῦτο σὺ μὲν οὐκ ἀρκῇ τοῖς σοῖς, ἀλλʼ ἐφίεσαι τῶν ἐκείνων· ἐκεῖνοι δʼ ἀρκοῦνται τοῖς ἑαυτῶν καὶ οὐκ ἐφίενται τῶν σῶν. ἐπεί τοι εἰ ταῖς ἀληθείαις ἐπέπεισο, ὅτι περὶ τὰ ἀγαθὰ σὺ ὁ ἐπιτυγχάνων εἶ, ἐκεῖνοι δʼ ἀποπεπλάνηνται, οὐδʼ ἂν ἐνεθυμοῦ, τί λέγουσι περὶ σοῦ.
english: To those who are distressed at being pitied. 'I am distressed,' someone says, 'because I am being pitied.' Tell me, is this business of being pitied your action, or the action of those who pity you? Is it in your power to stop it? 'It is, if I show them that I do not deserve pity.' But do you deserve pity right now, or do you not? 'I think I do not.' Yet these people do not pity you for the reasons you think—not for moral errors—but for poverty, lack of office, sickness, and death. Are you prepared, then to convince the mob that none of these things is an evil? No. The other path is to play the cheat: rent some slaves, possess a few silver vessels, show them off, dress in flashy clothes, and try to look like one of the 'important' people. This is the only way to escape their pity. The first way—convincing all mankind what is truly good and evil—is impossible; even Zeus could not do it. But has this not been given to you: to convince yourself? And you have not yet convinced yourself! And now you wish to convince others? Who has lived with you as long as you have with yourself? Who is more persuasive to you than you? Yet you are still unsettled. You have heard that the one path to freedom is to abandon things outside your will, yet you are bitten by pity. This proves you still think externals matter! Antisthenes said: 'It is a royal attribute, O Cyrus, to do good and be ill-spoken of.' My head is healthy, yet all think I have a headache; what do I care? I am poor, but I hold a correct judgment about poverty; what do I care if they pity me for it? They seek office; I seek right judgments. It is illogical for someone who puts no effort into a thing to expect the same reward as one who does. They wake up thinking of whom to flatter; you wake up thinking of how to keep your will in harmony with nature. If you were truly convinced that you possess the real Good and that they are the ones who are deceived, you would not even pay attention to what they say about you.
notes: In this lecture, Epictetus diagnoses a subtle contradiction in the student's mind. The student claims to be a philosopher but feels 'pain' when others pity him for his poverty or lack of status. Epictetus argues that this emotional reaction reveals a failure in the student's own training (askesis). If the student truly believed that poverty is indifferent (adiaphora) and that virtue is the only good, he would view the pity of the mob as a harmless error on their part, much like someone mistakenly thinking a healthy man has a headache. The anger at being pitied proves that the student still secretly values the opinion of the crowd and the material signs of success. The lesson emphasizes the 'Law of Trade-offs': one cannot pursue the internal peace of a philosopher while demanding the external reputation of a politician. You must choose one path and accept its consequences.

greek: περὶ ἀφοβίας. τί ποιεῖ φοβερὸν τὸν τύραννον; — οἱ δορυφόροι, φησίν, καὶ αἱ μάχαιραι αὐτῶν καὶ ὁ ἐπὶ τοῦ κοιτῶνος καὶ οἱ ἀποκλείοντες τοὺς εἰσιόντας. — διὰ τί οὖν, ἂν παιδίον αὐτῷ προσαγάγῃς μετὰ τῶν δορυφόρων ὄντι, οὐ φοβεῖται; ἢ ὅτι οὐκ αἰσθάνεται τούτων τὸ παιδίον; ἂν οὖν τῶν δορυφόρων τις αἰσθάνηται καὶ ὅτι μαχαίρας ἔχουσιν, ἐπʼ αὐτὸ δὲ τοῦτο προσέρχηται αὐτῷ θέλων ἀποθανεῖν διά τινα περίστασιν καὶ ζητῶν ὑπʼ ἄλλου παθεῖν αὐτὸ εὐκόλως, μή τι φοβεῖται τοὺς δορυφόρους; — θέλει γὰρ τοῦτο, διʼ ὃ φοβεροί εἰσιν. — ἂν οὖν τις μήτʼ ἀποθανεῖν μήτε ζῆν θέλων ἐξ ἅπαντος ἀλλʼ ὡς ἂν διδῶται, προσέρχηται αὐτῷ, τί κωλύει μὴ δεδοικότα προσέρχεσθαι αὐτόν; — οὐδέν. — ἄν τις οὖν καὶ πρὸς τὴν κτῆσιν ὡσαύτως ἔχῃ καθάπερ οὗτος πρὸς τὸ σῶμα καὶ πρὸς τὰ τέκνα καὶ τὴν γυναῖκα καὶ ἁπλῶς ὑπό τινος μανίας καὶ ἀπονοίας οὕτως ᾖ ν ν εἶτα ὑπὸ μανίας μὲν δύναταί τις οὕτως διατεθῆναι πρὸς ταῦτα καὶ ὑπὸ ἔθους οἱ Γαλιλαῖοι· ὑπὸ λόγου δὲ καὶ ἀποδείξεως οὐδεὶς δύναται μαθεῖν, ὅτι ὁ θεὸς πάντα πεποίηκεν τὰ ἐν τῷ κόσμῳ καὶ αὐτὸν τὸν κόσμον ὅλον μὲν ἀκώλυτον καὶ αὐτοτελῆ, τὰ ἐν μέρει δʼ αὐτοῦ πρὸς χρείαν τῶν ὅλων; τὰ μὲν οὖν ἄλλα πάντα ἀπήλλακται τοῦ δύνασθαι παρακολουθεῖν τῇ διοικήσει αὐτοῦ· τὸ δὲ λογικὸν ζῷον ἀφορμὰς ἔχει πρὸς ἀναλογισμὸν τούτων ἁπάντων, ὅτι τε μέρος ἐστὶ καὶ ποῖόν τι μέρος καὶ ὅτι τὰ μέρη τοῖς ὅλοις εἴκειν ἔχει καλῶς. πρὸς τούτοις δὲ φύσει γενναῖον καὶ μεγαλόψυχον καὶ ἐλεύθερον γενόμενον ὁρᾷ, διότι τῶν περὶ αὐτὸ τὰ μὲν ἀκώλυτα ἔχει καὶ ἐπʼ αὐτῷ, τὰ δὲ κωλυτὰ καὶ ἐπʼ ἄλλοις· ἀκώλυτα μὲν τὰ προαιρετικά, κωλυτὰ δὲ τὰ ἀπροαίρετα. καὶ διὰ τοῦτο, ἐὰν μὲν ἐν τούτοις μόνοις ἡγήσηται τὸ ἀγαθὸν τὸ αὑτοῦ καὶ συμφέρον, τοῖς ἀκωλύτοις καὶ ἐφʼ ἑαυτῷ, ἐλεύθερον ἔσται, εὔρουν, εὔδαιμον, ἀβλαβές, μεγαλόφρον, εὐσεβές, χάριν ἔχον ὑπὲρ πάντων τῷ θεῷ, μηδαμοῦ μεμφόμενον μηδενὶ τῶν γενομένων, μηδενὶ ἐγκαλοῦν· ἂν δʼ ἐν τοῖς ἐκτὸς καὶ ἀπροαιρέτοις, ἀνάγκη κωλύεσθαι αὐτό, ἐμποδίζεσθαι, δουλεύειν τοῖς ἐκείνων ἔχουσιν ἐξουσίαν, ἃ τεθαύμακεν καὶ φοβεῖται, ἀνάγκη δʼ ἀσεβὲς εἶναι ἅτε βλάπτεσθαι οἰόμενον ὑπὸ τοῦ θεοῦ καὶ ἄνισον, ἀεὶ αὑτῷ τοῦ πλείονος περιποιητικόν, ἀνάγκη δὲ καὶ ταπεινὸν εἶναι καὶ μικροπρεπές. ταῦτα τί κωλύει διαλαβόντα ζῆν κούφως καὶ εὐηνίως, πάντα τὰ συμβαίνειν δυνάμενα πρᾴως ἐκδεχόμενον, τὰ δʼ ἤδη συμβεβηκότα φέροντα; θέλεις πενίαν; θέλεις ἀρχάς; ἀλλʼ ἐξορισμόν; ἀλλʼ ἤδη καιρὸς ἀποθανεῖν. ἤδη καιρὸς τὴν ὕλην, ἐξ ὧν συνῆλθεν, εἰς ἐκεῖνα πάλιν ἀποκαταστῆναι. διὰ ταῦτα οἱ δορυφόροι μεγάλας δοκοῦσιν ἔχειν τὰς μαχαίρας καὶ ὀξείας; ἄλλοις ταῦτα· ἐμοὶ δʼ ἔσκεπται περὶ πάντων, εἰς ἐμὲ οὐδεὶς ἐξουσίαν ἔχει. ἠλευθέρωμαι ὑπὸ τοῦ θεοῦ, ἔγνωκα αὐτοῦ τὰς ἐντολάς, οὐκέτι οὐδεὶς δουλαγωγῆσαί με δύναται, καρπιστὴν ἔχω οἷον δεῖ, δικαστὰς οἵους δεῖ. οὐχὶ τοῦ σώματός σου κύριός εἰμι; οὐχὶ τοῦ κτησιδίου; οὐχὶ φυγῆς ἢ δεσμῶν; τίνα οὖν ἔτι φοβηθῆναι δύναμαι; τοὺς ἐπὶ τοῦ κοιτῶνος; μὴ τί ποιήσωσιν; ἀποκλείσωσί με; ἄν με εὕρωσι θέλοντα εἰσελθεῖν, ἀποκλεισάτωσαν. — τί οὖν ἔρχῃ ἐπὶ θύρας; — ὅτι καθήκειν ἐμαυτῷ δοκῶ μενούσης τῆς παιδιᾶς συμπαίζειν. — πῶς οὖν οὐκ ἀποκλείῃ; — ὅτι ἂν μή τίς με δέχηται, οὐ θέλω εἰσελθεῖν, ἀλλʼ ἀεὶ μᾶλλον ἐκεῖνο θέλω τὸ γινόμενον. κρεῖττον γὰρ ἡγοῦμαι ὃ ὁ θεὸς θέλει ἢ ὃ ἐγώ. προσκείσομαι διάκονος καὶ ἀκόλουθος ἐκείνῳ, συνορμῶ, συνορέγομαι, ἁπλῶς συνθέλω. ἀποκλεισμὸς ἐμοὶ οὐ γίνεται, ἀλλὰ τοῖς βιαζομένοις. διὰ τί οὖν οὐ βιάζομαι; οἶδα γάρ, ὅτι ἔσω ἀγαθὸν οὐδὲν διαδίδοται τοῖς εἰσελθοῦσιν. ἀλλʼ ὅταν ἀκούσω τινὰ μακαριζόμενον, ὅτι τιμᾶται ὑπὸ τοῦ Καίσαρος, λέγω τί αὐτῷ συμβαίνει; μή τι οὖν καὶ δόγμα, οἷον δεῖ ἐπαρχίαν; μή τι οὖν καὶ τὸ χρῆσθαι ἐπιτροπῇ; τί ἔτι διωθοῦμαι; ἰσχαδοκάρυά τις διαρριπτεῖ· τὰ παιδία ἁρπάζει καὶ ἀλλήλοις διαμάχεται· οἱ ἄνδρες οὐχί, μικρὸν γὰρ αὐτὸ ἡγοῦνται. ἂν δʼ ὀστράκια διαρριπτῇ τις, οὐδὲ τὰ παιδία ἁρπάζει. ἐπαρχίαι διαδίδονται· ὄψεται τὰ παιδία. ἀργύριον· ὄψεται τὰ παιδία. στρατηγία, ὑπατεία· διαρπαζέτω τὰ παιδία· ἐκκλειέσθω, τυπτέσθω, καταφιλείτω τὰς χεῖρας τοῦ διδόντος, τῶν δούλων· ἐμοὶ δʼ ἰσχαδοκάρυόν ἐστιν. τί οὖν, ἂν ἀπὸ τύχης ῥιπτοῦντος αὐτοῦ ἔλθῃ εἰς τὸν κόλπον ἰσχάς; ἄρας κατάφαγε· μέχρι τοσούτου γὰρ ἔστι καὶ ἰσχάδα τιμῆσαι. ἵνα δὲ κ ρ δείκνυέ μοι τὰς μαχαίρας τῶν δορυφόρων. ἰδοῦ, ἡλίκαι εἰσὶ καὶ πῶς ὀξεῖαι. ἀποκτ ε ἄλλο οὐδέν. ἄλλο οὐδέν. μὴ γένοιτο· ἀλλʼ ἅπαξ μαθών, ὅτι τὸ γενόμενον καὶ φθαρῆναι δεῖ, ἵνα ὁ κόσμος μὴ ἵστηται μηδʼ ἐμποδίζηται, οὐκέτι διαφέρομαι, πότερον πυρετὸς αὐτὸ ποιήσει ἢ κεραμὶς ἢ στρατιώτης, ἀλλʼ εἰ δεῖ συγκρῖναι, οἶδʼ ὅτι ἀπονώτερον αὐτὸ καὶ ταχύτερον ὁ στρατιώτης ποιήσει. ὅταν οὖν μήτε φοβῶμαί τι ὧν διαθεῖναί με δύναται μήτʼ ἐπιθυμῶ τινος ὧν παρασχεῖν, τί ἔτι θαυμάζω αὐτόν, τί ἔτι τέθηπα; τί φοβοῦμαι τοὺς δορυφόρους; τί χαίρω, ἄν μοι φιλανθρώπως λαλήσῃ καὶ ἀποδέξηταί με, καὶ ἄλλοις διηγοῦμαι, πῶς μοι ἐλάλησεν; μὴ γὰρ Σωκράτης ἐστίν, μὴ γὰρ Διογένης, ἵνʼ ὁ ἔπαινος αὐτοῦ ἀπόδειξις ᾖ περὶ ἐμοῦ; μὴ γὰρ τὸ ἦθος ἐζήλωκα αὐτοῦ; ἀλλὰ τὴν παιδιὰν σῴζων ἔρχομαι πρὸς εμ ἄπελθε ἐπὶ Λέοντα τὸν Σαλαμίνιον, ζήτει ἄλλον· ἐγὼ γὰρ οὐκέτι παίζω. ἄπαγε αὐτόν. ἀλλʼ ἀφαιρεῖταί σου ὁ τράχηλος. ἀλλʼ ἄταφος ῥιφήσῃ. τοῖς παιδίοις ταῦτα φοβερά ἐστι καὶ τοῖς ἀνοήτοις. εἰ δέ τις εἰς φιλοσόφου σχολὴν ἅπαξ εἰσελθὼν οὐκ οἶδεν, τί ἐστιν αὐτός, ἄξιός ἐστι φοβεῖσθαι καὶ κολακεύειν ὃ ναί· ἀλλʼ οἱ λόγοι οὗτοι καταφρονητὰς ποιοῦσι τῶν νόμων. — καὶ ποῖοι μᾶλλον λόγοι πειθομένους παρέχουσι τοῖς νόμοις τοὺς χρωμένους; νόμος δʼ οὐκ ἔστι τὰ ἐπὶ μωρῷ. καὶ ὅμως ὅρα, πῶς καὶ πρὸς τούτους ὡς δεῖ ἔχοντας παρασκευάζουσιν, οἵ γε διδάσκουσιν μηδενὸς ἀντιποιεῖσθαι πρὸς αὐτούς, ἐν οἷς ἂν ἡμᾶς νικῆσαι δύνωνται. περὶ τὸ σωμάτιον διδάσκουσιν ἐξίστασθαι, περὶ τὴν κτῆσιν ἐξίστασθαι, περὶ τὰ τέκνα, γονεῖς δʼ ποία ἐνθάδε παρανομία, ποία ἀβελτερία; ὅπου κρείττων εἶ καὶ ἰσχυρότερος, ἐκεῖ σοι ἐξίσταμαι· ὅπου πάλιν ἐγὼ κρείττων, σὺ παραχώρει μοι. ἐμοὶ γὰρ μεμέληκεν, σοὶ δʼ οὔ. σοὶ μέλει, πῶς ἐν ὀρθοστρώτοις οἰκῇς, ἔτι πῶς παῖδές σοι καὶ πιλλᾶτοι διακονῶσιν, πῶς ἐσθῆτα περίβλεπτον φορῇς, πῶς κυνηγοὺς πολλοὺς ἔχῃς, πῶς κιθαρῳδούς, τραγῳδούς. μή τι ἀντιποιοῦμαι; μή τι οὖν δογμάτων σοι μεμέληκε; μή τι τοῦ λόγου τοῦ σεαυτοῦ; μή τι οἶδας, ἐκ τίνων μορίων συνέστηκεν, πῶς συνάγεται, τίς ἡ διάρθρωσις αὐτοῦ, τίνας ἔχει δυνάμεις καὶ ποίας τινάς; τί οὖν ἀγανακτεῖς, εἰ ἄλλος ἐν τούτοις σου πλέον ἔχει ὁ μεμελετηκώς; — ἀλλὰ ταῦτʼ ἔστι τὰ μέγιστα. — καὶ τίς σε κωλύει περὶ ταῦτʼ ἀναστρέφεσθαι καὶ τούτων ἐπιμελεῖσθαι; τίς δὲ μείζονα ἔχει παρασκευὴν βιβλίων, εὐσχολίας, τῶν ὠφελησόντων; μόνον ἀπόνευσόν ποτε ἐπὶ ταῦτα, ἀπόνειμον κἂν ὀλίγον χρόνον τῷ σαυτοῦ ἡγεμονικῷ· σκέψαι τί ποτʼ ἔχεις τοῦτο καὶ πόθεν ἐληλυθός, τὸ πᾶσιν τοῖς ἄλλοις χρώμενον, πάντα τἆλλα δοκιμάζον, ἐκλεγόμενον, ἀπεκλεγόμενον. μέχρι δʼ ἂν οὗ περὶ τὰ ἐκτὸς ἀναστρέφῃ, ἐκεῖνα ἕξεις οἷα οὐδείς, τοῦτο δʼ οἷον αὐτὸ ἔχειν θέλεις, ῥυπαρὸν καὶ ἀτημέλητον.
english:
What makes the tyrant terrifying? Is it the guards, their tall stature, and their sharp swords? Is it the chamberlain who blocks the door? Why, then, if you bring a small child before them, is he not afraid? Is it not because the child does not comprehend these things? Now, consider a man who wishes to die—perhaps seeking relief from some agony—and actively seeks a quick end at another's hand. Does he fear the guards? No, for he desires the very thing they are equipped to do. 

So, if a man were to hold the same attitude toward his possessions, his body, and his children as that man holds toward death—if, through reason rather than madness or mere habit (like the Galileans), he understood that God made the world self-sufficient but its parts to serve the whole—who could possibly master him? 

The rational animal has the capacity to understand its place in the universe. He sees that some things are unhindered and within his power (prohairesis), while others are hindered and dependent on others. If he locates his Good solely in the unhindered—his choices—he will be free, happy, and pious, blaming no one. But if he locates his Good in externals, he must necessarily be thwarted, enslaved, and impious, for he will resent God for his losses. 

Why are the guards' swords 'long and sharp'? To others, perhaps. To me, they are nothing. I have been set free by God; I know His commandments. No one can enslave me anymore. I have the right liberator and the right judges. Am I the master of my body? No. Of my little property? No. Of exile or chains? No. What, then, is left for me to fear? 

'But he will shut you out of the palace!' Let him shut me out if he finds me wishing to enter. 'Why do you go to the door then?' Because as long as the game continues, I think it fitting to play. 'But surely you will be shut out.' If I am not welcomed, I do not wish to enter; I always prefer what actually happens to what I wanted to happen. I consider what God wills to be better than what I will. I attach myself to Him as a servant and follower; my impulses, my desires, my will are one with His. 

Listen to me: when you see people fighting over political posts and honors, imagine someone scattering figs and nuts. Children scramble and fight for them; grown men do not. Governorships are being distributed? Let the children scramble. Money? Let the children scramble. To me, these are mere figs and nuts. If one falls into my lap by chance, I may eat it, for one may value a fig that much—but I will not stoop and fight for it. 

'Show me the swords,' you say. Look how sharp they are! And what do they do? They kill the body. Nothing else? Nothing else. Very well. Once I have learned that everything born must perish so the universe may continue, it matters not to me whether a fever kills me or a soldier. In fact, the soldier is quicker. 

Therefore, do not envy the tyrant's favorites. They pay a price for their figs and nuts. You cannot have both the external prize and a clean, free Ruling Faculty. As long as you obsess over the external, your mind will remain dirty and neglected, while you admire the trinkets of slaves.
notes: This discourse is a masterclass in 'Aphobia' (fearlessness). Epictetus argues that fear is not caused by objects (tyrants, swords) but by our judgments regarding them. 1) The nature of invincibility: If you do not value what the tyrant controls (body, property, life), he has no handle by which to grasp you. You are only vulnerable if you desire what is not 'up to you.' 2) The 'Galileans' (Christians) reference: Epictetus notes their fearlessness of death but attributes it to habit/fanaticism, contrasting it with the Stoic fearlessness derived from reason and proof. 3) The 'Figs and Nuts' metaphor: This is essential Epictetian imagery. External goods (office, wealth) are toys. A philosopher may accept them if given ('falling in the lap'), but to fight for them is childish and undignified. 4) Alignment with the Divine: The ultimate freedom is 'Amor Fati'—loving fate. By aligning one's will with God's will (what actually happens), one can never be 'shut out' or disappointed. 5) The cost of freedom: You cannot have the peace of the philosopher and the perks of the courtier. You must choose between cultivating your 'Hegemonikon' (ruling faculty) or chasing external 'figs.'

greek: πρὸς τοὺς ταχέως ἐπὶ τὸ σχῆμα τῶν φιλοσόφων ἐπιπηδῶντας. μηδέποτʼ ἀπὸ τῶν κοινῶν τινα μήτʼ ἐπαινέσητε μήτε ψέξητε μήτε τέχνην τινὰ ἢ ἀτεχνίαν προσμαρτυρήσητε· καὶ ἅμα μὲν προπετείας ἑαυτοὺς ἀπαλλάξετε, ἅμα δὲ κακοηθείας. οὗτος ταχέως λούεται. ἀλλὰ τί; ταχέως λούεται. — πάντα οὖν καλῶς γίνεται; — οὐδαμῶς· ἀλλὰ τὰ μὲν ἀπὸ δογμάτων ὀρθῶν καλῶς, τὰ δʼ ἀπὸ μοχθηρῶν μοχθηρῶς. σὺ δὲ μέχρις ἂν καταμάθῃς τὸ δόγμα, ἀφʼ οὗ τις ποιεῖ ἕκαστα, μήτʼ ἐπαίνει τὸ ἔργον μήτε ψέγε. δόγμα δʼ ἐκ τῶν ἐκτὸς οὐ ῥᾳδίως κρίνεται. οὗτος τέκτων ἐστίν. χρῆται σκεπάρνῳ. οὗτος μουσικός· ᾁδει γάρ. οὗτος φιλόσοφος. τρίβωνα γὰρ ἔχει καὶ κόμην. ἰδοὺ ὁ φιλόσοφος τί ποιεῖ. εἰ μὲν γὰρ αὕτη ἐστὶν ἡ τοῦ φιλοσόφου πρόληψις καὶ ἐπαγγελία, ἔχειν τρίβωνα καὶ κόμην, καλῶς ἂν ἔλεγον· εἰ δʼ ἐκείνη μᾶλλον, ἀναμάρτητον εἶναι, διὰ τί οὐχὶ διὰ τὸ μὴ πληροῦν τὴν ἐπαγγελίαν ἀφαιροῦνται αὐτὸν τῆς προσηγορίας; οὕτως γὰρ καὶ ἐπὶ τῶν ἄλλων τεχνῶν. ὅταν ἴδῃ τις κακῶς πελεκῶντα, οὐ λέγει τί ὄφελος τεκτονικῆς; ἰδοὺ οἱ τέκτονες οἷα ποιοῦσι κακά, οὗτος οὐκ ἔστι τέκτων, πελεκᾷ γὰρ κακῶς. ὁμοίως κἂν ᾁδοντός τινος ἀκούσῃ κακῶς, οὐ λέγει ἰδοὺ πῶς ᾁδουσιν οἱ μουσικοί, οὗτος ὅτι ἐπὶ φιλοσοφίας δὲ μόνης τοῦτο πάσχουσιν· ὅταν τινὰ ἴδωσι παρὰ τὸ ἐπάγγελμα τὸ τοῦ φιλοσόφου ποιοῦντα, οὐχὶ τῆς προσηγορίας ἀφαιροῦνται αὐτόν, ἀλλὰ θέντες εἶναι φιλόσοφον, εἶτʼ ἀπʼ αὐτοῦ τοῦ γινομένου λαβόντες, ὅτι ἀσχημονεῖ, ἐπάγουσι μηδὲν ὄφελος εἶναι τοῦ φιλοσοφεῖν. τί οὖν τὸ αἴτιον; ὅτι τὴν μὲν τοῦ τέκτονος πρόληψιν πρεσβεύομεν καὶ τὴν τοῦ μουσικοῦ καὶ ὡσαύτως τῶν ἄλλων τεχνιτῶν, τὴν τοῦ φιλοσόφου δʼ οὔ, ἀλλʼ ἅτε συγκεχυμένην καὶ ἀδιάρθρωτον ἀπὸ τῶν ἐκτὸς μόνον κρίνομεν. καὶ ποία ἄλλη τέχνη ἀπὸ σχήματος ἀναλαμβάνεται καὶ κόμης, οὐχὶ δὲ καὶ θεωρήματα ἔχει καὶ ὕλην καὶ τέλος; τίς οὖν ὕλη τοῦ φιλοσόφου; μὴ τρίβων; οὔ, ἀλλὰ ὁ λόγος. τί τέλος; μή τι φορεῖν τρίβωνα; οὔ, ἀλλὰ τὸ ὀρθὸν ἔχειν τὸν λόγον. ποῖα θεωρήματα; μή τι τὰ περὶ τοῦ πῶς πώγων μέγας γίνεται ἢ κόμη βαθεῖα; ἀλλὰ μᾶλλον ἃ Ζήνων λέγει, γνῶναι τὰ τοῦ λόγου στοιχεῖα, ποῖόν τι ἕκαστον αὐτῶν ἐστι καὶ πῶς ἁρμόττεται πρὸς ἄλληλα καὶ ὅσα τούτοις ἀκόλουθά ἐστιν. οὐ θέλεις οὖν ἰδεῖν πρῶτον, εἰ πληροῖ τὴν ἐπαγγελίαν ἀσχημονῶν, καὶ οὕτως τῷ ἐπιτηδεύματι ἐγκαλεῖν; νῦν δʼ, αὐτὸς ὅταν σωφρονῇς, ἐξ ὧν ποιεῖν σοι δοκεῖ κακῶς, λέγεις ὅρα τὸν φιλόσοφον τοῦτο φιλόσοφός ἐστιν. ὅρα τὸν τέκτονα ὅρα τὸν μουσικόν. οὕτως ἐπὶ ποσὸν αἰσθάνῃ καὶ αὐτὸς τῆς ἐπαγγελίας τοῦ φιλοσόφου, ἀπολισθάνεις δὲ καὶ συγχέῃ ὑπὸ ἀμελετησίας. ἀλλὰ καὶ αὐτοὶ οἱ καλούμενοι φιλόσοφοι ἀπὸ τῶν κοινῶν τὸ πρᾶγμα μετίασιν· εὐθὺς ἀναλαβόντες τρίβωνα καὶ πώγωνα καθέντες φασὶν ἐγὼ φιλόσοφός εἰμι. οὐδεὶς δʼ ἐρεῖ ἐγὼ μουσικός εἰμι, ἐγὼ χαλκεύς εἰμι, διὰ τοῦτο καλῶς Εὐφράτης ἔλεγεν ὅτι ἐπὶ πολὺ ἐπειρώμην λανθάνειν φιλοσοφῶν καὶ ἦν μοι, τοῦτο ὠφέλιμον. πρῶτον μὲν γὰρ ᾔδειν, ὅσα καλῶς ἐποίουν, ὅτι οὐ διὰ τοὺς θεατὰς ἐποίουν, ἀλλὰ διʼ ἐμαυτόν· ἤσθιον ἐμαυτῷ καλῶς, κατεσταλμένον εἶχον τὸ βλέμμα, τὸν περίπατον· πάντα ἐμαυτῷ καὶ θεῷ. εἶτα ὥσπερ μόνος ἠγωνιζόμην, οὕτως μόνος καὶ ἐκινδύνευον· οὐδὲν ἐμοὶ δράσαντι τὸ αἰσχρὸν ἢ ἀπρεπὲς τὸ τῆς φιλοσοφίας ἐκινδυνεύετο, οὐδʼ ἔβλαπτον τοὺς πολλοὺς ὡς φιλόσοφος ἁμαρτάνων. διὰ τοῦτο οἱ μὴ εἰδότες μου τὴν ἐπιβολὴν ἐθαύμαζον, πῶς πᾶσι φιλοσόφοις χρώμενος καὶ συζῶν αὐτὸς οὐκ ἐφιλοσόφουν. καὶ τί κακόν, ἐν οἷς ἐποίουν ἐπιγιγνώσκεσθαι τὸν φιλόσοφον, ἐν δὲ τοῖς συμβόλοις μή; εἰ δʼ οὕτως κωφὸς εἶ καὶ τυφλός, ἵνα μηδὲ τὸν Ἥφαιστον ὑπολαμβάνῃς καλὸν χαλκέα, ἂν μὴ τὸ πιλίον ἴδῃς περὶ τὴν κεφαλὴν περικείμενον, τί κακὸν ὑφʼ οὕτως ἠλιθίου κριτοῦ ἀγνοεῖσθαι; οὕτως ἐλάνθα νε παρὰ τοῖς πλείστοις Σωκράτης καὶ ἤρχοντο πρὸς αὐτὸν ἀξιοῦντες φιλοσόφοις συσταθῆναι. μή τι οὖν ἠγανάκτει ὡς ἡμεῖς καὶ ἔλεγεν ἐγὼ δέ σοι οὐ φαίνομαι φιλόσοφος;; τί ἔργον καλοῦ καὶ ἀγαθοῦ; μαθητὰς πολλοὺς ἔχειν; οὐδαμῶς. ὄψονται οἱ περὶ τοῦτο ἐσπουδακότες. ἀλλὰ θεωρήματα δύσκολα ἀκριβοῦν; ὄψονται καὶ περὶ τούτων ἄλλοι. ποῦ οὖν αὐτὸς καὶ ἦν τις καὶ εἶναι ἤθελεν; ὅπου βλάβη καὶ ὠφέλεια. εἴ μέ τις, βλάψαι δύναται, ἐγὼ οὐδὲν ποιῶ· εἰ ἄλλον περιμένω, ἵνα με ὠφελήσῃ, ἐγὼ οὐδέν εἰμι. θέλω τι καὶ οὐ γίνεται· ἐγὼ ἀτυχής εἰμι. εἰς τοσοῦτο σκάμμα προεκαλεῖτο πάντα ὁντιναοῦν καὶ οὐκ ἄν μοι δοκεῖ ἐκστῆναι οὐδενί — τί δοκεῖτε; καταγγέλλων καὶ λέγων ἐγὼ τοιοῦτός εἰμι; πάλιν γὰρ τοῦτο μωροῦ καὶ ἀλαζόνος ἐγὼ ἀπαθής εἰμι καὶ ἀτάραχος· μὴ ἀγνοεῖτε, ὦ ἄνθρωποι, ὅτι ὑμῶν κυκωμένων καὶ θορυβουμένων περὶ τὰ μηδενὸς ἄξια μόνος ἐγὼ ἀπήλλαγμαι πάσης ταραχῆς. οὕτως οὐκ ἀρκεῖ σοι τὸ μηδὲν ἀλγεῖν, ἂν μὴ κηρύσσῃς συνέλθετε πάντες οἱ ποδαγρῶντες, οἱ κεφαλαλγοῦντες, οἱ πυρέσσοντες, οἱ χωλοί, οἱ τυφλοί, καὶ ἴδετέ με ἀπὸ παντὸς πάθους ὑγιᾶ; τοῦτο κενὸν καὶ φορτικόν, εἰ μή τι ς τοιοῦτος γάρ τίς ἐστιν ὁ Κυνικὸς τοῦ σκήπτρου καὶ διαδήματος ἠξιωμένος παρὰ τοῦ Διὸς καὶ λέγων ἵνʼ ἴδητε, ὦ ἄνθρωποι, ὅτι τὴν εὐδαιμονίαν καὶ ἀταραξίαν οὐχ ὅπου ἐστὶ ζητεῖτε, ἀλλʼ ὅπου μή ἐστιν, ἰδοὺ ἐγὼ ὑμῖν παράδειγμα ὑπὸ τοῦ θεοῦ ἀπέσταλμαι μήτε κτῆσιν ἔχων μήτε οἶκον μήτε γυναῖκα μήτε τέκνα, ἀλλὰ μηδʼ ὑπόστρωμα μηδὲ χιτῶνα μηδὲ σκεῦος· καὶ ἴδετε, πῶς ὑγιαίνω· πειράθητέ μου κἂν ἴδητε ἀτάραχον, ἀκούσατε τὰ φάρμακα καὶ ὑφʼ ὧν ἐθεραπεύθην. τοῦτο γὰρ ἤδη καὶ φιλάνθρωπον καὶ γενναῖον. ἀλλʼ ὁρᾶτε, τίνος ἔργον ἐστίν· τοῦ Διὸς ἢ ὃν ἂν ἐκεῖνος ἄξιον κρίνῃ ταύτης τῆς ὑπηρεσίας, ἵνα μηδαμοῦ μηδὲν παραγυμνώσῃ πρὸς τοὺς πολλούς, διʼ οὗ τὴν μαρτυρίαν τὴν αὑτοῦ, ἣν τῇ ἀρετῇ μαρτυρεῖ καὶ τῶν ἐκτὸς καταμαρτυρεῖ, αὐτὸς ἄκυρον ποιήσῃ· καὶ οὐ μόνον ταῦτα, ἀλλʼ οὐδὲ ποθοῦντά τι ἢ ἐπιζητοῦντα, ἄνθρωπον ἢ τόπον ἢ διαγωγήν, ὡς τὰ παιδία τὸν τρυγητὸν ἢ τὰς ἀργίας, αἰδοῖ πανταχοῦ κεκοσμημένον, ὡς οἱ ἄλλοι τοίχοις καὶ θύραις καὶ θυρωροῖς. νῦν δʼ αὐτὸ μόνον κινηθέντες πρὸς φιλοσοφίαν, ὡς οἱ κακοστόμαχοι πρός τι βρωμάτιον, ὃ μετὰ μικρὸν σικχαίνειν μέλλουσιν, εὐθὺς ἐπὶ τὸ σκῆπτρον, ἐπὶ τὴν βασιλείαν. καθεῖκε τὴν κόμην, ἀνείληφε τρίβωνα, γυμνὸν δεικνύει τὸν ὦμον, μάχεται τοῖς ἀπαντῶσιν κἂν ἐν φαινόλῃ τινὰ ἴδῃ, μάχεται αὐτῷ. ἄνθρωπε, χειμάσκησον πρῶτον· ἰδοῦ σου τὴν ὁρμήν, μὴ κακοστομάχου ἢ κισσώσης γυναικός ἐστιν. ἀγνοεῖσθαι μελέτησον πρῶτον, τίς εἶ· σαυτῷ φιλοσόφησον ὀλίγον χρόνον. οὕτως καρπὸς γίνεται· κατορυγῆναι δεῖ εἰς χρόνον τὸ σπέρμα, κρυφθῆναι, κατὰ μικρὸν αὐξηθῆναι, ἵνα τελεσφορήσῃ. ἂν δὲ πρὸ τοῦ γόνυ φῦσαι τὸν στάχυν ἐξενέγκῃ, ἀτελές ἐστιν, ἐκ κήπου Ἀδωνιακοῦ. τοιοῦτον εἶ καὶ σὺ φυτάριον· θᾶττον τοῦ δέοντος ἤνθηκας, ἀποκαύσει σε ὁ χειμών. ἰδοῦ, τί λέγουσιν οἱ γεωργοὶ περὶ τῶν σπερμάτων, ὅταν πρὸ ὥρας θερμασίαι γένωνται. ἀγωνιῶσιν, μὴ ἐξυβρίσῃ τὰ σπέρματα, εἶτα αὐτὰ πάγος εἷς λαβὼν ἐξελέγξῃ. ὅρα καὶ σύ, ἄνθρωπε· ἐξύβρικας, ἐπιπεπήδηκας δοξαρίῳ πρὸ ὥρας· δοκεῖς τις εἶναι, μωρὸς παρὰ μωροῖς· ἀποπαγήσῃ, μᾶλλον δʼ ἀποπέπηγας ἤδη ἐν τῇ ῥίζῃ κάτω, τὰ δʼ ἄνω σου μικρὸν ἔτι ἀνθεῖ καὶ διὰ τοῦτο δοκεῖς ἔτι ζῆν καὶ θάλλειν. ἄφες ἡμᾶς γε κατὰ φύσιν πεπανθῆναι. τί ἡμᾶς ἀποδύεις, τί βιάζῃ; οὔπω δυνάμεθα ἐνεγκεῖν τὸν ἀέρα. ἔασον τὴν ῥίζαν αὐξηθῆναι, εἶτα γόνυ λαβεῖν τὸ πρῶτον, εἶτα τὸ δεύτερον, εἶτα τὸ τρίτον· εἶθʼ οὕτως ὁ καρπὸς ἐκβιάσεται τὴν φύσιν, κἂν ἐγὼ μὴ θέλω. τίς γὰρ ἐγκύμων γενόμενος καὶ πλήρης τηλικούτων δογμάτων οὐχὶ αἰσθάνεταί τε τῆς αὑτοῦ παρασκευῆς καὶ ἐπὶ τὰ κατάλληλα ἔργα ὁρμᾷ; ἀλλὰ ταῦρος μὲν οὐκ ἀγνοεῖ τὴν αὑτοῦ φύσιν καὶ παρασκευήν, ὅταν ἐπιφανῇ τι θηρίον, οὐδʼ ἀναμένει τὸν προτρεψόμενον, οὐδὲ κύων, ὅταν ἴδῃ τι τῶν ἀγρίων ζῴων· ἐγὼ δʼ ἂν ἴσχω τὴν ἀνδρὸς ἀγαθοῦ παρασκευήν, ἐκδέξομαι, ἵνα με σὺ παρασκευάσῃς ἐπὶ τὰ οἰκεῖα ἔργα; νῦν δʼ οὔπω ἔχω, πίστευσόν μοι. τί οὖν με πρὸ ὥρας ἀποξηρᾶναι θέλεις, ὡς αὐτὸς ἐξηράνθης;
english: To those who hastily rush to assume the guise of philosophers: Never praise or blame anyone on account of common externals, nor ascribe to them skill or lack of skill; by doing so, you will free yourself from both rashness and malice. 'This man bathes quickly.' Does he do it badly? No, only quickly. 'Is everything done well, then?' By no means; actions done from right principles are done well, and those from bad principles, badly. But until you understand the principle from which a man acts, do not praise the work nor blame it. A principle, however, is not easily judged from the outside. 'This man is a carpenter.' Why? 'He uses an adze.' 'This man is a musician.' Why? 'He sings.' 'This man is a philosopher.' Why? 'Because he wears a rough cloak and has long hair.' Yet, look at what philosophers actually do. If the profession of a philosopher is merely to wear a cloak and hair, then they are right; but if it is rather to keep the ruling faculty free from error, why do we not strip the title from those who fail to fulfill the profession? We do this in other trades. If you see someone hacking badly with an axe, you do not say, 'What is the use of carpentry?' You say, 'This man is no carpenter.' But in philosophy alone, when people see someone acting contrary to the profession, they do not take away the title; instead, assuming he is a philosopher and seeing his shameful behavior, they conclude that philosophy itself is useless. The cause is that we respect the definition of the carpenter, but regarding the philosopher, our definition is confused and judged only by externals. What is the subject matter of the philosopher? The cloak? No, it is Reason. What is the end? To wear a cloak? No, to possess right Reason. Therefore, Euphrates spoke well when he said, 'I tried to conceal that I was a philosopher for a long time, and this was beneficial to me.' For I knew that whatever I did well, I did not do for the spectators, but for myself and for God. It was I alone who struggled, and I alone who faced the danger. If I did anything shameful, the cause of philosophy was not endangered; nor did I harm the masses by sinning as a philosopher. Why is it bad to be recognized as a philosopher by your actions, but not by your insignia? Socrates was so hidden from the masses that they came to him asking to be introduced to philosophers. Did he get angry and say, 'Do I not look like a philosopher to you?' No. Man, undergo winter training first! Look at your impulse; see if it is not just a weak stomach or the craving of a pregnant woman. Practice concealing who you are for a while; philosophize for yourself. Fruit is produced in this way: the seed must first be buried for a time, hidden, and grown by degrees, so that it may come to perfection. But if you produce the ear before the stalk has jointed, it is imperfect—a mere plant for the Garden of Adonis. You are such a plant; you have blossomed too soon, and the winter will scorch you up. Let us ripen naturally. Why do you strip us? Why do you force us? We cannot yet bear the air. Let the root grow, then the first joint, then the second; then the fruit will force its way out naturally, even if I do not will it. For who, when he is pregnant with such great principles, does not perceive his own capacity and rush toward the appropriate actions? A bull is not ignorant of his own nature and capacity when a wild beast appears; he does not wait for someone to encourage him. If I have the equipment of a good man, I will show it. But now I do not yet have it; believe me. Why then do you wish to wither me away before my time, just as you have been withered?
notes: In this discourse, Epictetus attacks the vanity of 'costume philosophy'—the tendency of students to adopt the beard, cloak, and staff of the philosopher before they have actually internalized the doctrines. The core lesson is the distinction between 'Acting' (displaying the symbols of virtue) and 'Being' (possessing the ruling principle of virtue). Epictetus uses the metaphor of agriculture: a seed must be buried and hidden to develop strong roots before it can bear fruit. If a plant shoots up too quickly (the 'Garden of Adonis,' referring to quick-sprouting herbs used in rituals that died immediately), it will be destroyed by the first frost (adversity). Practical application: 1) Do not judge others by their appearance or job titles, but by the principles (dogmata) that drive their actions. 2) Do not announce yourself as a Stoic to the world. Conceal your progress. Let your actions speak only when your principles are so engrained that they cannot be shaken. 3) Doing good 'for oneself and for God' is the antidote to vanity; if you need an audience to be virtuous, you are not yet a philosopher.

greek: πρὸς τὸν εἰς ἀναισχυντίαν μεταβληθέντα. ὅταν ἄλλον ἴδῃς ἄρχοντα, ἀντίθες, ὅτι σὺ ἔχεις τὸ μὴ δεῖσθαι ἀρχῆς· ὅταν ἄλλον πλουτοῦντα, ἰδοῦ, τί ἀντὶ τούτου ἔχεις. εἰ μὲν γὰρ μηδὲν ἔχεις ἀντʼ αὐτοῦ, ἄθλιος εἶ· εἰ δʼ ἔχεις τὸ μὴ χρείαν ἔχειν πλούτου, γίγνωσκε, ὅτι πλεῖον ἔχεις καὶ πολλῷ πλείονος ἄξιον. ἄλλος γυναῖκα εὔμορφον, σὺ τὸ μὴ ἐπιθυμεῖν εὐμόρφου γυναικός. μικρά σοι δοκεῖ ταῦτα; καὶ πόσου ἂν τιμήσαιντο οὗτοι αὐτοὶ οἱ πλουτοῦντες καὶ ἄρχοντες καὶ μετʼ εὐμόρφων διαιτώμενοι δύνασθαι πλούτου καταφρονεῖν καὶ ἀρχῶν καὶ αὐτῶν τούτων τῶν γυναικῶν, ὧν ἐρῶσιν καὶ ὧν τυγχάνουσιν; ἀγνοεῖς οἷόν τί ἐστι δίψος πυρέσσοντος; οὐδὲν ὅμοιον ἔχει τῷ τοῦ ὑγιαίνοντος. ἐκεῖνος πιὼν ἀποπέπαυται· ὁ δὲ πρὸς ὀλίγον ἡσθεὶς ναυτιᾷ, χολὴν αὐτὸ ποιεῖ ἀντὶ ὕδατος, ἐμεῖ, στροφοῦται, διψῇ σφοδρότερον. τοιοῦτόν ἐστι μετʼ ἐπιθυμίας πλουτεῖν, μετʼ ἐπιθυμίας ἄρχειν, μετʼ ἐπιθυμίας καλῇ συγκαθεύδειν· ζηλοτυπία πρόσεστιν, φόβος τοῦ στερηθῆναι, αἰσχροὶ λόγοι, αἰσχρὰ ἐνθυμήματα, ἔργα ἀσχήμονα. καὶ τί, φησίν, ἀπολλύω;— ἄνθρωπε, ὑπῆρχες αἰδήμων καὶ νῦν οὐκέτι εἶ· οὐδὲν ἀπολώλεκας; ἀντὶ Χρυσίππου καὶ Ζήνωνος Ἀριστείδην ἀναγιγνώσκεις καὶ Εὐηνόν· οὐδὲν ἀπολώλεκας; ἀντὶ Σωκράτους καὶ Διογένους τεθαύμακας τὸν πλείστας διαφθεῖραι καὶ ἀναπεῖσαι δυνάμενον. καλὸς εἶναι θέλεις καὶ πλάσσεις σεαυτὸν μὴ ὢν καὶ ἐσθῆτα ἐπιδεικνύειν θέλεις στιλπνήν, ἵνα τὰς γυναῖκας ἐπιστρέφῃς, κἄν που μυραφίου ἐπιτύχῃς, μακάριος εἶναι δοκεῖς. πρότερον δʼ οὐδὲ ἐνεθυμοῦ τι τούτων, ἀλλὰ ποῦ εὐσχήμων λόγος, ἀνὴρ ἀξιόλογος, ἐνθύμημα γενναῖον. τοιγαροῦν ἐκάθευδες ὡς ἀνήρ, προῄεις ὡς ἀνήρ, ἐσθῆτα ἐφόρεις ἀνδρικήν, λόγους ἐλάλεις πρέποντας ἀνδρὶ ἀγαθῷ· εἶτά μοι λέγεις οὐδὲν ἀπώλεσα; οὕτως οὐδὲν ἄλλο ἢ κέρμα ἀπολλύουσιν ἄνθρωποι; αἰδὼς οὐκ ἀπόλλυται, εὐσχημοσύνη οὐκ ἀπόλλυται; ἢ οὐκ ἔστι ζημιωθῆναι ταῦτα ἀπολέσαντα; σοὶ μὲν οὖν δοκεῖ τάχα τούτων οὐδὲν οὐκέτι εἶναι ζημία· ἦν δέ ποτε χρόνος, ὅτε μόνην αὐτὴν ὑπελογίζου καὶ ζημίαν καὶ βλάβην, ὅτε ἠγωνίας, μή τις ἐκσείσῃ σε τούτων τῶν λόγων καὶ ἔργων. ἰδού, ἐκσέσεισαι ὑπʼ ἄλλου μὲν οὐδενός, ὑπὸ σαυτοῦ δέ. μαχέσθητι σαυτῷ, ἀφελοῦ σαυτὸν εἰς εὐσχημοσύνην, εἰς αἰδῶ, εἰς ἐλευθερίαν. εἴ σοί τίς που ἔλεγεν περὶ ἐμοῦ ταῦτα, ὅτι μέ τις μοιχεύειν ἀναγκάζει, ὅτι ἐσθῆτα φορεῖν τοιαύτην, ὅτι μυρίζεσθαι, οὐκ ἂν ἀπελθὼν αὐτόχειρ ἐγένου τούτου τοῦ ἀνθρώπου τοῦ οὕτως μοι παραχρωμένου; νῦν οὖν οὐ θέλεις σαυτῷ βοηθῆσαι; καὶ πόσῳ ῥᾴων αὕτη ἡ βοήθεια; οὐκ ἀποκτεῖναί τινα δεῖ, οὐ δῆσαι, οὐχ ὑβρίσαι, οὐκ εἰς ἀγορὰν προελθεῖν, ἀλλʼ αὐτὸν αὑτῷ λαλῆσαι, τῷ μάλιστα πεισθησομένῳ, πρὸς ὃν οὐδείς ἐστί σου πιθανώτερος. καὶ πρῶτον μὲν κατάγνωθι τῶν γιγνομένων, εἶτα καταγνοὺς μὴ ἀπογνῷς σεαυτοῦ μηδὲ πάθῃς τὸ τῶν ἀγεννῶν ἀνθρώπων, οἳ ἅπαξ ἐνδόντες εἰσάπαν ἐπέδωκαν ἑαυτοὺς καὶ ὡς ὑπὸ ῥεύματος παρεσύρησαν, ἀλλὰ μάθε τὸ τῶν παιδοτριβῶν. πέπτωκε τὸ παιδίον· ἀναστάς, πάλιν πάλαιε, μέχρις ἂν ἰσχυροπο ι τοιοῦτόν τι καὶ σὺ πάθε· ἴσθι γάρ, ὅτι οὐδέν ἐστιν εὐαγωγότερον ἀνθρωπίνης ψυχῆς. θελῆσαι δεῖ καὶ γέγονεν, διώρθωται· ὡς πάλιν ἀπονυστάσαι καὶ ἀπόλωλεν. ἔσωθεν γάρ ἐστι καὶ ἀπώλεια καὶ βοήθεια. — εἶτα τί μοι ἀγαθόν; — καὶ τί ζητεῖς τούτου μεῖζον; ἐξ ἀναισχύντου αἰδήμων ἔσῃ, ἐξ ἀκόσμου κόσμιος, ἐξ ἀπίστου πιστός, ἐξ ἀκολάστου σώφρων. εἴ τινα ἄλλα τούτων μείζονα ζητεῖς, ποίει ἃ ποιεῖς· οὐδὲ θεῶν σέ τις ἔτι σῶσαι δύναται.
english: To the person who has lapsed into shamelessness. When you see another man in power, set this against it: that you possess the advantage of not needing power. When you see another man rich, look and see what you have instead. For if you have nothing in its place, you are indeed miserable; but if you have the independence of not needing wealth, know that you possess something greater and of far more value. Another possesses a beautiful woman; you possess the power of not desiring a beautiful woman. Do these things seem small to you? And how much would these very men—the rich, the powerful, and those who live with beautiful women—pay to be able to despise wealth and power and those very women whom they love and possess? Do you not realize what the thirst of a fever is like? It bears no resemblance to the thirst of a healthy man. The healthy man drinks and his thirst ceases. But the other is pleased for a moment, then becomes nauseous, turns the drink into bile, vomits, gets cramps, and thirsts even more violently. Such is the condition of the man who is rich with desire, who holds office with desire, who sleeps with a beautiful woman with desire: jealousy comes with it, fear of loss, shameful words, shameful thoughts, and unseemly deeds. 'And what,' he asks, 'am I losing?' Man, you used to be modest, and now you are not. Have you lost nothing? Instead of Chrysippus and Zeno, you now read Aristeides and Evenus. Have you lost nothing? Instead of Socrates and Diogenes, you admire the man who can corrupt and seduce the most women. You want to be handsome and you make yourself up, though you are not; you want to display flashy clothes to attract women's attention; and if you find some cheap perfume, you think yourself happy. Formerly, you did not think of any of these things; but where now is your decent speech, your character as a man of worth, your noble thinking? So, you used to sleep like a man, walk like a man, wear a man's clothes, and speak in a way that befits a good man; and yet you say to me, 'I have lost nothing'? Do men lose nothing but coins? Is modesty not lost? Is decency not lost? Or does the man who loses these things suffer no penalty? Perhaps you think that none of these things matters anymore; yet there was a time when you accounted this the only loss and damage, when you were anxious lest anyone should shake you from these principles and actions. Look, you have been shaken from them, not by another, but by yourself. Fight against yourself; reclaim yourself for decency, for modesty, for freedom. If someone had told you these things about me—that someone was forcing me to commit adultery, to wear such clothes, to scent myself with perfume—would you not have gone and killed the man who so abused me? But now, will you not help yourself? And how much easier is this help? There is no need to kill anyone, nor to fetter him, nor to insult him, nor to go out into the market, but only to speak to yourself, the person who will be most easily persuaded, and with whom no one has more influence than you. First, condemn what you are doing; then, having condemned it, do not despair of yourself, nor be like those ignoble people who, having once given in, surrender themselves completely and are swept away as if by a torrent. Rather, learn from the wrestling masters. The boy has fallen? 'Get up,' he says, 'and wrestle again until you are made strong.' You should experience something similar. For know that nothing is more tractable than the human soul. You need only to will it, and the thing is done; the correction is made. But nod off, and all is lost. For both ruin and salvation come from within. — 'What good, then, do I get?' — And what greater good are you looking for than this? You will be modest instead of shameless, orderly instead of disorderly, faithful instead of untrustworthy, self-controlled instead of dissolute. If you are looking for anything greater than these things, go right ahead and do what you are doing; for not even a god can save you now.
notes: Epictetus employs a powerful 'exchange rate' argument here: external power and wealth are purchased at the cost of internal peace and freedom. If one has 'nothing' (no virtue) to replace external lack, one is truly wretched; but the Sage realizes that 'not needing' is a superior asset to 'having.' The Discourse utilizes the famous 'fever analogy' to explain the pathology of desire (passions). Unlike a healthy thirst which is satisfied by water, a feverish thirst (desire) turns the object of desire into 'bile' (nausea/anxiety), creating a cycle of increasing dissatisfaction and sickness. Epictetus attacks the student's vanity—likely a student who has abandoned philosophy for the life of a fop or a seducer—contrasting the serious study of Stoic founders (Zeno, Chrysippus) with reading erotica (Aristeides). The core lesson is on the plasticity of the human will (prohairesis). Moral corruption is not permanent unless we allow it to be. The remedy is internal dialogue and 'wrestling'—getting back up immediately after a fall. The ultimate reward of Stoicism is not external gain, but the restoration of one's own character: becoming faithful, modest, and free.

thematic_lexicon.lexicon_entry: The divine, rational principle organizing the universe.
The immanent creative reason within matter.
A physical substance (pneuma) giving life to the body.
A sense of honor, shame, and self-respect.
A rational, social animal.
The morally beautiful; only virtue is truly good.

greek: τίνων δεῖ καταφρονεῖν καὶ πρὸς τίνα διαφέρεσθαι. ἀπορία πᾶσι τοῖς ἀνθρώποις περὶ τὰ ἐκτὸς γίνεται, ἀμηχανία περὶ τὰ ἐκτός. τί ποιήσω; πῶς γένηται; πῶς ἀποβῇ; μὴ τόδε ἀπαντήσῃ, μὴ τόδε. πᾶσαι αὗται αἱ φωναὶ περὶ τὰ ἀπροαίρετα στρεφομένων εἰσίν· τίς γὰρ λέγει πῶς μὴ συγκατατιθῶμαι τῷ ψεύδει; πῶς μὴ ἀπονεύσω ἀπὸ τοῦ ἀληθοῦς; ἐὰν οὕτως ᾖ εὐφυής, ὥστε περὶ τούτων ἀγωνιᾶν, ὑπομνήσω αὐτὸν ὅτι τί ἀγωνιᾷς; ἐπὶ σοί ἐστιν· ἀσφαλὴς ἴσθι· μὴ πρὸ τοῦ ἐπάγειν τὸν φυσικὸν κανόνα προπήδα ἐν τῷ συγκατατίθεσθαι. πάλιν ἂν περὶ ὀρέξεως μὴ περὶ ἐκκλίσεως, μὴ περιπτωτική, πρῶτον μὲν αὐτὸν καταφιλήσω, ὅτι ἀφεὶς περὶ ἃ οἱ ἄλλοι ἐπτόηνται καὶ τοὺς ἐκείνων φόβους περὶ τῶν ἰδίων ἔργων πεφρόντικεν, ὅπου αὐτός ἐστιν· εἶτα ἐρῶ αὐτῷ εἰ μὴ θέλῃς ὀρέγεσθαι ἀποτευκτικῶς μηδʼ ἐκκλίνειν περιπτωτικῶς, μηδενὸς ὀρέγου τῶν ἀλλοτρίων, μηδὲν ἔκκλινε τῶν μὴ ἐπὶ σοί. εἰ δὲ μή, καὶ ἀποτυχεῖν καὶ περιπεσεῖν ἀνάγκη. ποία ἐνθάδʼ ἀπορία; ποῦ τόπον ἔχει πῶς γένηται; πῶς ἀποβῇ; μὴ ἀπαντήσῃ τόδε ἢ τόδε; νῦν οὐχὶ τὸ ἐκβησόμενον ἀπροαίρετον;— ναί. — ἡ δʼ οὐσία τοῦ ἀγαθοῦ καὶ κακοῦ ἐστιν ἐν τοῖς προαιρετικοῖς; — ναί. — ἔξεστιν οὖν σοι παντὶ τῷ ἀποβάντι χρῆσθαι κατὰ φύσιν; μή τις σε κωλῦσαι δύναται; — οὐδείς. — μηκέτι οὖν μοι λέγε πῶς γένηται; ἢ τίς ἂν ἦν ὁ Ἡρακλῆς λέγων πῶς μοι μὴ μέγας λέων ἐπιφανῇ μηδὲ μέγας σῦς μηδὲ θηριώδεις ἄνθρωποι; — ἂν οὖν οὕτως ἀποθάνω; — ἀγαθὸς ὢν ἀποθανῇ, γενναίαν πρᾶξιν ἐπιτελῶν ἐπεὶ γὰρ δεῖ πάντως ἀποθανεῖν, ἀνάγκη τί ποτε ποιοῦντα εὑρεθῆναι, ἢ γεωργοῦντα ἢ σκάπτοντα ἢ ἐμπορευόμενον ἢ ὑπατεύοντα ἢ ἀπεπτοῦντα ἢ διαρροιζόμενον. τί οὖν θέλεις ποιῶν εὑρεθῆναι ὑπὸ τοῦ θανάτου; ἐγὼ μὲν τὸ ἐμὸν μέρος ἔργον τί ποτε ἀνθρωπικόν, εὐεργετικόν, κοινωφελές, γενναῖον. εἰ δὲ μὴ δύναμαι τὰ τηλικαῦτα ποιῶν εὑρεθῆναι, ἐκεῖνό γε τὸ ἀκώλυτον, τὸ διδόμενον, ἐμαυτὸν ἐπανορθῶν, ἐξεργαζόμενος τὴν δύναμιν τὴν χρηστικὴν τῶν φαντασιῶν, ἀπάθειαν ἐκπονῶν, ταῖς σχέσεσι τὰ οἰκεῖα ἀποδιδούς· εἰ οὕτως εὐτυχής εἰμι, καὶ τοῦ τρίτου τόπου παραπτόμενος, τοῦ περὶ τὴν τῶν κριμάτων ἀσφάλειαν. ἂν μετὰ τούτων με ὁ θάνατος καταλάβῃ, ἀρκεῖ μοι ἂν δύνωμαι πρὸς τὸν θεὸν ἀνατεῖναι τὰς χεῖρας, εἰπεῖν ὅτι ἃς ἔλαβον ἀφορμὰς παρὰ σοῦ πρὸς τὸ αἰσθέσθαι σου τῆς διοικήσεως καὶ ἀκολουθῆσαι αὐτῇ, τούτων οὐκ ἠμέλησα· οὐ κατῄσχυνά σε τὸ ἐμὸν μέρος. ἰδοῦ, πῶς κέχρημαι ταῖς αἰσθήσεσιν, ἰδοῦ, πῶς ταῖς προλήψεσιν. μή ποτέ σε ἐμεμψάμην, μή τι τῶν γινομένων τινὶ δυσηρέστησα ἢ ἄλλως γενέσθαι ἠθέλησα, μή τι τὰς σχέσεις παρέβην αι ὅ με σὺ ἐγέννησας, χάριν ἔχω, ὧν ἔδωκας· ἐφʼ ὅσον ἐχρησάμην τοῖς σοῖς, ἀρκεῖ μοι. πάλιν αὐτὰ ἀπόλαβε καὶ κατάταξον εἰς ἣν θέλεις χώραν. σὰ γὰρ ἦν πάντα, σύ μοι αὐτὰ δέδωκας. οὐκ ἀρκεῖ οὕτως ἔχοντα ἐξελθεῖν; καὶ τίς βίων κρείττων ἢ εὐσχημονέστερος τοῦ οὕτως ἔχοντος, ποία δὲ καταστροφὴ εὐδαιμονεστέρα; ἵνα δὲ ταῦτα γένηται, οὐ μικρὰ δέξασθαι οὐδὲ μικρῶν ἀποτυχεῖν. οὐ δύνασαι καὶ ὑπατεῦσαι θέλειν καὶ ταῦτα καὶ ἀγροὺς ἔχειν ἐσπουδακέναι καὶ ταῦτα καὶ τῶν δουλαρίων φροντίζειν καὶ σεαυτοῦ. ἀλλʼ ἄν τι τῶν ἀλλοτρίων θέλῃς, τὰ σὰ ἀπώλετο. αὕτη τοῦ πράγματος ἡ φύσις· προῖκα οὐδὲν γίνεται. καὶ τί θαυμαστόν; ἂν ὑπατεῦσαι θέλῃς, ἀγρυπνῆσαί σε δεῖ, περιδραμεῖν, τὰς χεῖρας καταφιλῆσαι, πρὸς ταῖς ἀλλοτρίαις θύραις κατασαπῆναι, πολλὰ μὲν εἰπεῖν, πολλὰ δὲ πρᾶξαι ἀνελεύθερα, δῶρα πέμψαι πολλοῖς, ξένια καθʼ ἡμέραν ἐνίοις· καὶ τί τὸ γινόμενόν ἐστιν; δώδεκα δεσμὰ ῥάβδων καὶ τρὶς ἢ τετράκις ἐπὶ βῆμα καθίσαι καὶ κιρκήσια δοῦναι καὶ σπυρίσιν δειπνίσαι. ἢ δειξάτω μοί τις, τί ἐστι παρὰ ταῦτα. ὑπὲρ ἀπαθείας οὖν, ὑπὲρ ἀταραξίας, ὑπὲρ τοῦ καθεύδοντα καθεύδειν, ἐγρηγορότα ἐγρηγορέναι, μὴ φοβεῖσθαι μηδέν, μὴ ἀγωνιᾶν ὑπὲρ μηδενὸς οὐδὲν ἀναλῶσαι θέλεις, οὐδὲν πονῆσαι; ἀλλʼ ἄν τι ἀπόληταί σου περὶ ταῦτα γινομένου ἢ ἀναλωθῇ κακῶς ἢ ἄλλος τύχῃ ὧν ἔδει σε τυχεῖν, εὐθὺς μὴ οὐκ ἀντιθήσεις, τί ἀντὶ τίνος λαμβάνεις, πόσον ἀντὶ πόσου; ἀλλὰ προῖκα θέλεις τὰ τηλικαῦτα λαβεῖν; καὶ πῶς δύνασαι; ἔργον ἔργῳ. οὐ δύνασαι καὶ τὰ ἐκτὸς ἔχειν ἐπιμελείας τετυχηκότα καὶ τὸ σαυτοῦ ἡγεμονικόν. εἰ δʼ ἐκεῖνα θέλεις, τοῦτο ἄφες· εἰ δὲ μή, οὔτε τοῦτο ἕξεις οὔτʼ ἐκεῖνα, περισπώμενος ἐπʼ ἀμφότερα. εἰ τοῦτο θέλεις, ἐκεῖνά σε ἀφεῖναι δεῖ. ἐκχεθήσεται τὸ ἔλαιον, ἀπολεῖται τὰ σκευάρια, ἀλλʼ ἐγὼ ἀπαθὴς ἔσομαι. ἐμπρησμὸς ἔσται ἐμοῦ μὴ παρόντος καὶ ἀπολεῖται τὰ βιβλία, ἀλλʼ ἐγὼ χρήσομαι ταῖς φαντασίαις κατὰ φύσιν. ἀλλʼ οὐχ ἕξω φαγεῖν. εἰ οὕτως τάλας εἰμί, λιμὴν τὸ ἀποθανεῖν. οὗτος δʼ ἐστὶν ὁ λιμὴν πάντων, ὁ θάνατος, αὕτη ἡ καταφυγή. διὰ τοῦτο οὐδὲν τῶν ἐν τῷ βίῳ χαλεπόν ἐστιν. ὅταν θέλῃς, ἐξῆλθες καὶ οὐ καπνίζῃ. τί οὖν ἀγωνιᾷς, τί ἀγρυπνεῖς; οὐχὶ δὲ εὐθὺς ἀναλογισάμενος, ποῦ σου τὸ ἀγαθόν ἐστι καὶ τὸ κακόν, λέγεις ὅτι ἐπʼ ἐμοὶ ἀμφότερα· οὔτε τούτου τις ἀφελέσθαι με δύναται οὔτʼ ἐκείνῳ ἄκοντα περιβαλεῖν. τί οὖν οὐ ῥέγχω βαλών; τὰ ἐμὰ ἀσφαλῶς ἔχει· τὰ ἀλλότρια ὄψεται αὐτὰ ὃς ἂν φέρῃ, ὡς ἂν διδῶται παρὰ τοῦ ἔχοντος ἐξουσίαν. τίς εἰμι ὁ θέλων αὐτὰ οὕτως ἔχειν ἢ οὕτως; μὴ γάρ μοι δέδοται ἐκλογὴ αὐτῶν; μὴ γὰρ ἐμέ τις αὐτῶν διοικητὴν πεποίηκεν; ἀρκεῖ μοι ὧν ἔχω ἐξουσίαν. ταῦτά με δεῖ κάλλιστα παρασκευάσαι, τὰ δʼ ἄλλα ὡς ἂν θέλῃ ὁ ἐκείνων κύριος. ταῦτά τις ἔχων πρὸ ὀφθαλμῶν ἀγρυπνεῖ, καὶ στρέφεται ἔνθα καὶ ἔνθα; τί θέλων ἢ τί ποθῶν; Πάτροκλον ἢ Ἀντίλοχον ἢ Μενέλαον; πότε γὰρ ἡγήσατο ἀθάνατόν τινα τῶν φίλων; πότε γὰρ οὐκ εἶχεν πρὸ ὀφθαλμῶν, ὅτι αὔριον ἢ εἰς τρίτην δεῖ ἢ αὐτὸν ἀποθανεῖν ἢ ἐκεῖνον; ναί, ἀλλʼ ᾤμην, ὅτι ἐκεῖνος ἐπιβιώσεταί μοι καὶ αὐξήσει μου τὸν υἱόν. ἀλλʼ ἐκεῖνός μοι φαγεῖν παρετίθει. ἂν δʼ ἡ χύτρα, ἐν ᾗ ἥψετό σοι τὸ κρέας, καταγῇ, λιμῷ σε δεῖ ἀποθανεῖν, ὅτι μὴ ἔχεις τὴν συνήθη χύτραν; οὐ πέμπεις καὶ ἄλλην καινὴν ἀγοράζεις; φησίν, τί δοκεῖτε; μὴ ἐπίτηδες ταῦτα συνθεῖναι Ὅμηρον, ἵνʼ ἴδωμεν, ὅτι οἱ εὐγενέστατοι, οἱ ἰσχυρότατοι, οἱ πλουσιώτατοι, οἱ εὐμορφότατοι, ὅταν οἷα δεῖ δόγματα μὴ ἔχωσιν, οὐδὲν κωλύονται ἀθλιώτατοι εἶναι καὶ δυστυχέστατοι;
english: Turn your mind to this: What things deserve our contempt, and over what things must we be vigilant? All human perplexity, all confusion, arises concerning external things. You hear people cry, 'What shall I do? How will it turn out? Let not this or that befall me!' These are the voices of men whose concern revolves around things outside the sphere of their own will. For who asks, 'How shall I not assent to what is false? How shall I not turn away from the truth?' If a man is naturally gifted enough to be anxious about these things, I will remind him: 'Why are you anxious? It is in your own power. Be at peace. Do not rush to assent before applying the rule of nature.' Again, if his anxiety concerns his desires—lest they fail—or his aversions—lest he fall into what he avoids—I will first embrace him, because he has cast aside the terrors that make others tremble and has focused his care on his own business, where his true self lies. Then I will say to him: 'If you would not fail in your desires or fall into what you avoid, desire nothing that belongs to others; avoid nothing that is not in your own control. If you do otherwise, you must necessarily fail and fall into disaster.' What room is there for perplexity here? What place is there for 'How will it turn out?' or 'I hope this doesn't happen'? Is not the outcome independent of your will? Yes. And is not the essence of good and evil in the sphere of your will? Yes. Is it not then in your power to make use of whatever happens in accordance with nature? Can anyone hinder you? No one. Then say no longer to me, 'How will it turn out?' For who would Hercules have been if he had said, 'I hope a great lion does not appear to me, or a great boar, or savage men?' If he had stayed at home wrapped in bedclothes, what would he have become? Certainly no Hercules. But since you must die regardless, you must necessarily be found doing something when death arrives—farming, perhaps, or digging, or trading, or serving as Consul, or suffering indigestion or dysentery. What, then, do you wish to be doing when death finds you? For my part, I wish to be found doing some work that belongs to a human being—beneficent, useful to the common good, noble. If I cannot be found doing such great things, I would at least be doing what none can hinder, what is given to me to do: correcting my own self, perfecting the faculty that makes use of impressions, laboring to achieve freedom from passion, and rendering what is due in my relationships. If I am this fortunate, death may find me reaching for the third topic—the security of my judgments. If death overtakes me in such a state, it is enough if I can lift up my hands to God and say: ' The faculties which I received from You to understand Your administration and to follow it, I have not neglected. I have not dishonored You as far as in me lay. See how I have used my perceptions; see how I have used my preconceptions. Have I ever blamed You? Have I been discontented with any event, or wished it otherwise? Have I transgressed my relationships? That You gave me life, I thank You for what You gave; so long as I have used what is Yours, it suffices me. Take them back again and place them where You will. For they were all Yours, and You gave them to me.' Is it not enough to leave the world in this state of mind? What life is better or more becoming than that of such a man? What end is more happy? But for this to happen, you must endure no small things, nor miss no small things. You cannot wish to be Consul and also wish for this; you cannot act to acquire lands and also this; you cannot worry about your slaves and also about yourself. If you want anything that belongs to others, what is your own is lost. This is the nature of the transaction: nothing is given for nothing. And what is strange in that? If you want to be Consul, you must keep awake, run about, kiss hands, rot at the doors of others, say and do many slavish things, send gifts to many, and daily presents to some. And what is the result? Twelve bundles of rods, to sit three or four times on the tribunal, to give games in the Circus, and to distribute baskets of food. Or let someone show me what else there is besides this. Will you then pay nothing for freedom from passion, for tranquility, for sleeping when you sleep, for being awake when you wake, for fearing nothing, for being anxious about nothing? But if anything belonging to you is lost while you are attending to these things, or is spent unprofitably, or another gets what you ought to have had, will you not immediately set against it what you acquire instead of it? How much for how much? Do you want to receive such great things for nothing? And how can you? One work against another. You cannot have external things well cared for and your own ruling faculty well cared for at the same time. If you want the former, let the latter go. If you do not, you will have neither the one nor the other, being distracted between both. 'The oil will be spilled, the grand furniture will perish, but I shall be free from passion.' 'There will be a fire when I am not there, and my books will be destroyed, but I shall use my impressions in accordance with nature.' 'But I shall have nothing to eat.' If I am so wretched, death is the harbor. That is the harbor of all, death; that is the refuge. For this reason, nothing in life is difficult. When you wish, you walk out, and you are not suffocated with smoke. Why then are you anxious? Why do you keep awake? Why do you not calculate where your good and evil lie, and say, 'Both are in my own power; no one can take the one from me, nor involve me in the other against my will'? Why then do I not snore at my ease? My own things are safe; what belongs to others, he will look to who bears them, however they may be given by Him who has the power. Who am I, to wish them to be so or so? Has a choice been given to me? Has anyone made me the administrator of them? It is enough for me that I have power over what belongs to me. This I must make as beautiful as possible; the rest must be as the Master of those things wills. Does a man who has these things before his eyes keep awake and turn from side to side? What does he wish, or what does he long for? Patroclus, or Antilochus, or Menelaus? For when did he think that any of his friends was immortal? When had he not before his eyes that on the morrow or the third day he or his friend must die? 'Yes, but I thought that he would survive me and bring up my son.' 'But he used to set food before me.' If the pot is broken in which your meat was cooked, must you die of hunger because you do not have your accustomed pot? Do you not send and buy another new one? He says: 'What do you think? Did not Homer compose these things on purpose, that we might see that the noblest, the strongest, the richest, the most beautiful, when they have not the dogmas which they ought to have, are not prevented from being most wretched and most unfortunate?'
notes: In this discourse, Epictetus presents the dichotomy of control as an economic transaction. He argues that anxiety ('What will happen?') is a symptom of misplaced value—caring for things not up to us. He uses the metaphors of Hercules and the political candidate to illustrate the cost of virtue. Hercules became Hercules only through adversity; the politician gains the Consulship only by selling his dignity. Epictetus demands we make a choice: we can 'buy' external success with our freedom, or we can 'buy' tranquility (apatheia) by sacrificing external attachments. He reframes death not as a catastrophe, but as a 'harbor' and a final accounting to God, where we return our borrowed faculties with gratitude. The reference to Achilles (mourning Patroclus) serves as a warning: even the greatest heroes are wretched if they lack correct judgments (dogmata) about mortality and the nature of the good.

greek: περὶ καθαριότητος. ἀμφισβητοῦσί τινες, εἰ ἐν τῇ φύσει τοῦ ἀνθρώπου περιέχεται τὸ κοινωνικόν· ὅμως δʼ αὐτοὶ οὗτοι οὐκ ἄν μοι δοκοῦσιν ἀμφισβητῆσαι, ὅτι τό γε καθάριον πάντως περιέχεται καὶ εἴ τινι ἄλλῳ καὶ τούτῳ τῶν ζῴων χωρίζεται. ὅταν οὖν ἄλλο τι ζῷον ἴδωμεν ἀποκαθαῖρον ἑαυτό, ἐπιλέγειν εἰώθαμεν θαυμάζοντες ὅτι ὡς ἄνθρωπος. οὐ δήπου ἄνθρωπός ἐστιν. οὕτως ἐξαίρετόν τι περὶ τὸν ἄνθρωπον εἶναι οἰόμεθα ἀπὸ τῶν θεῶν αὐτὸ πρῶτον λαμβάνοντες. ἐπεὶ γὰρ ἐκεῖνοι φύσει καθαροὶ καὶ ἀκήρατοι, ἐφʼ ὅσον ἠγγίκασιν αὐτοῖς οἱ ἄνθρωποι κατὰ τὸν λόγον, ἐπὶ τοσοῦτον καὶ τοῦ καθαροῦ καὶ τοῦ καθαρίου εἰσὶν ἀνθεκτικοί. ἐπεὶ δʼ ἀμήχανον τὴν οὐσίαν αὐτῶν παντάπασιν εἶναι καθαρὰν ἐκ τοιαύτης ὕλης κεκραμένην, ὁ λόγος παραληφθεὶς εἰς τὸ ἐνδεχόμενον ταύτην καθάριον ἀποτελεῖν πειρᾶται. πρώτη οὖν καὶ ἀνωτάτω καθαρότης ἡ ἐν ψυχῇ γενομένη καὶ ὁμοίως ἀκαθαρσία. ψυχῆς δʼ ὡς σώματος μὲν ἀκαθαρσίαν οὐκ ἂν εὕροις, ὡς ψυχῆς δὲ τί ἂν ἄλλο εὕροις ἢ τὸ παρέχον αὐτὴν ῥυπαρὰν πρὸς τὰ ἔργα τὰ αὑτῆς; ἔργα δὲ ψυχῆς ὁρμᾶν, ἀφορμᾶν, ὀρέγεσθαι, ἐκκλίνειν, παρασκευάζεσθαι, ἐπιβάλλεσθαι, συγκατατίθεσθαι. τί ποτʼ οὖν ἐστι τὸ ἐν τούτοις τοῖς ἔργοις ῥυπαρὰν παρέχον αὐτὴν καὶ ἀκάθαρτον; οὐδὲν ἄλλο ἢ τὰ μοχθηρὰ κρίματα αὐτῆς. ὥστε ψυχῆς μὲν ἀκαθαρσία δόγματα πονηρά, κάθαρσις δʼ ἐμποίησις οἵων δεῖ δογμάτων. καθαρὰ δʼ ἡ ἔχουσα οἷα δεῖ δόγματα· μόνη γὰρ αὕτη ἐν τοῖς ἔργοις τοῖς αὑτῆς ἀσύγχυτος καὶ ἀμόλυντος. δεῖ δέ τι ἐοικὸς τούτῳ καὶ ἐπὶ σώματος φιλοτεχνεῖν κατὰ τὸ ἐνδεχόμενον. ἀμήχανον ἦν μύξας μὴ ῥεῖν τοῦ ἀνθρώπου τοιοῦτον ἔχοντος τὸ σύγκραμα· διὰ τοῦτο χεῖρας ἐποίησεν ἡ φύσις καὶ αὐτὰς τὰς ῥῖνας ὡς σωλῆνας πρὸς τὸ ἐκδιδόναι τὰ ὑγρά. ἂν οὖν ἀναρροφῇ τις αὐτάς, λέγω ὅτι οὐ ποιεῖ ἔργον ἀνθρωπικόν. ἀμήχανον ἦν μὴ πηλοῦσθαι τοὺς πόδας μηδὲ ὅλως μολύνεσθαι διὰ τοιούτων τινῶν πορευομένους· διὰ τοῦτο ὕδωρ παρεσκεύασεν, διὰ τοῦτο χεῖρας. ἀμήχανον ἦν ἀπὸ τοῦ τρώγειν μὴ ῥυπαρόν τι προσμένειν τοῖς ὀδοῦσι· διὰ τοῦτο πλῦνον, τοὺς ὀδόντας. ἀμήχανον μὴ ἀπὸ τοῦ ἱδρῶτος καὶ τῆς κατὰ τὴν ἐσθῆτα συνοχῆς ὑπολείπεσθαί τι περὶ τὸ σῶμα ῥυπαρὸν καὶ δεόμενον ἀποκαθάρσεως· διὰ τοῦτο ὕδωρ, ἔλαιον, χεῖρες, ὀθόνιον, ξύστρα, νίτρον, ἔσθʼ ὅθʼ ἡ ἄλλη πᾶσα παρασκευὴ πρὸς τὸ καθῆραι αὐτό. οὔ· ἀλλʼ ὁ μὲν χαλκεὺς ὡς χαλκεὺς — διὰ τί; φησίν. — πάλιν ἐρῶ σοι· πρῶτον μὲν ἵνα τὰ ἀνθρώπου ποιῇς, εἶτα ἵνα μὴ ἀνιᾷς τοὺς ἐντυγχάνοντας. τοιοῦτόν τι καὶ ἐνθάδε ποιεῖς καὶ οὐκ αἰσθάνῃ. σαυτὸν ἄξιον ἡγῇ τοῦ ὄζειν· ἔστω, ἴσθι ἄξιος. μή τι καὶ τοὺς παρακαθίζοντας, μή τι καὶ τοὺς συγκατακλινομένους, μή τι καὶ τοὺς καταφιλοῦντας; ἢ ἄπελθʼ εἰς ἐρημίαν πού ποτε, ἧς ἄξιος εἶ, καὶ μόνος δίαγε κατόζων σεαυτοῦ. δίκαιον γάρ ἐστι τῆς σῆς ἀκαθαρσίας σὲ μόνον ἀπολαύειν. ἐν πόλει δʼ ὄντα οὕτως ἀπερισκέπτως καὶ ἀγνωμόνως ἀναστρέφεσθαι τίνος σοι φαίνεται; εἰ δʼ ἵππον σοι πεπιστεύκει ἡ φύσις, περιεώρας αὐτὸν καὶ ἀτημέλητον; καὶ νῦν οἴου σου τὸ σῶμα ὡς ἵππον ἐγκεχειρίσθαι· πλῦνον αὐτό, ἀπόσμηξον, ποίησον, ἵνα σε μηδεὶς ἀποστρέφηται, μηδεὶς ἐκτρέπηται. τίς δʼ οὐκ ἐκτρέπεται ῥυπαρὸν ἄνθρωπον, ὄζοντα, κακόχρουν μᾶλλον ἢ τὸν κεκοπρωμένον; ἐκείνη ἡ ὀσμὴ ἔξωθέν ἐστιν ἐπίθετος, ἡ δʼ ἐξ ἀθεραπευσίας ἔσωθεν καὶ οἱονεὶ διασεσηπότος. ἀλλὰ Σωκράτης ὀλιγάκις ἐλούετο.— ἀλλὰ ἔστιλβεν αὐτοῦ τὸ σῶμα, ἀλλʼ ἦν οὕτως ἐπίχαρι καὶ ἡδύ, ὥστʼ ἤρων αὐτοῦ οἱ ὡραιότατοι καὶ εὐγενέστατοι καὶ ἐπεθύμουν ἐκείνῳ παρακατακλίνεσθαι μᾶλλον ἢ τοῖς εὐμορφοτάτοις. ἐξῆν ἐκείνῳ μήτε λούεσθαι μήτε πλύνεσθαι, εἰ ἤθελεν· καίτοι καὶ τὸ ὀλιγάκις ἰσχὺν εἶχεν. κἂν θερμῷ μὴ θέλῃς, ψυχρῷ. — ἀλλὰ λέγει Ἀριστοφάνης ἐπεί τοι πάντες οἱ γεγραφότες περὶ Σωκράτους πάντα τἀναντία αὐτῷ προσμαρτυροῦσιν, ὅτι ἡδὺς οὐ μόνον ἀκοῦσαι, ἀλλὰ καὶ ἰδεῖν ἦν. πάλιν περὶ Διογένους ταὐτὰ γράφουσι. δεῖ γὰρ μηδὲ κατὰ τὴν ἀπὸ τοῦ σώματος ἔμφασιν ἀπὸ φιλοσοφίας ἀποσοβεῖν τοὺς πολλούς, ἀλλʼ ὥσπερ τὰ ἄλλα εὔθυμον καὶ ἀτάραχον ἐπιδεικνύειν αὑτὸν οὕτως καὶ ἀπὸ τοῦ σώματος. ἴδετε, ὦ ἄνθρωποι, ὅτι οὐδὲν ἔχω, οὐδενὸς δέομαι· ἴδετε, πῶς ἄοικος ὢν καὶ ἄπολις καὶ φυγάς, ἂν οὕτως τύχῃ, καὶ ἀνέστιος πάντων τῶν εὐπατριδῶν καὶ πλουσίων ἀταραχώτερον διάγω καὶ εὐρούστερον. ἀλλὰ καὶ τὸ σωμάτιον ὁρᾶτε ὅτι οὐ κακοῦται ὑπὸ τῆς αὐστηρᾶς διαίτης. ἂν δέ μοι ταῦτα λέγῃ τις ἀνθρώπου σχῆμα καταδίκου ἔχων καὶ πρόσωπον, τίς με πείσει θεῶν προσελθεῖν φιλοσοφίᾳ, ἥ γε τοιούτους ποιεῖ; μὴ γένοιτο· οὐδʼ, εἰ σοφὸς ἔμελλον εἶναι, ἤθελον. ἐγὼ μὲν νὴ τοὺς θεοὺς τὸν νέον τὸν πρώτως κινούμενον θέλω μᾶλλον ἐλθεῖν πρός με πεπλασμένον τὴν κόμην ἢ κατεφθινηκότα καὶ ῥυπαρόν. βλέπεται γάρ τις ἐν ἐκείνῳ τοῦ καλοῦ φαντασία, ἔφεσις δὲ τοῦ εὐσχήμονος. ὅπου δʼ αὐτὸ ν λοιπὸν ὑποδεῖξαι μόνον αὐτῷ δεῖ καὶ εἰπεῖν νεανίσκε, τὸ καλὸν ζητεῖς καὶ εὖ ποιεῖς. ἴσθι οὖν, ὅτι ἐκεῖ φύεται, ὅπου τὸν λόγον ἔχεις· ἐκεῖ αὐτὸ ζήτει, ὅπου τὰς ὁρμὰς καὶ τὰς ἀφορμάς, ὅπου τὰς ὀρέξεις, τὰς ἐκκλίσεις. τοῦτο γὰρ ἔχεις ἐν σεαυτῷ ἐξαίρετον, τὸ σωμάτιον δὲ φύσει πηλός ἐστιν. τί πονεῖς εἰκῇ περὶ αὐτό; εἰ μηδὲν ἕτερον, τῷ χρόνῳ γνώσῃ, ὅτι οὐδέν ἐστιν. ἂν δέ μοι ἔλθῃ κεκοπρωμένος, ῥυπαρός, μύστακα ἔχων μέχρι τῶν γονάτων, τί αὐτῷ εἰπεῖν ἔχω, ἀπὸ ποίας αὐτὸν ὁμοιότητος ἐπαγαγεῖν; περὶ τί γὰρ ἐσπούδακεν ὅμοιον τῷ καλῷ, ἵνʼ αὐτὸν μεταθῶ καὶ εἴπω οὐκ ἔστιν ἐνθάδε τὸ καλόν, ἀλλʼ ἐνθάδε; οὐκ ἔστιν ἐν τῷ κεκοπρῶσθαι τὸ καλόν, ἀλλʼ ἐν τῷ λόγῳ; διὰ τοῦτο καὶ Πολέμωνος ἥψαντο οἱ λόγοι οἱ Ξενοκράτους ὡς φιλοκάλου νεανίσκου· εἰσῆλθεν γὰρ ἔχων ἐναύσματα τῆς περὶ τὸ καλὸν σπουδῆς, ἀλλαχοῦ δʼ αὐτὸ ζητῶν. ἐπεί τοι οὐδὲ τὰ ζῷα τὰ ἀνθρώποις σύντροφα ῥυπαρὰ ἐποίησεν ἡ φύσις. μή τι ἵππος κυλίεται ἐν βορβόρῳ, μή τι κύων γενναῖος; ἀλλʼ ὁ ὗς καὶ τὰ σαπρὰ χηνίδια καὶ σκώληκες καὶ ἀράχναι, τὰ μακροτάτω τῆς ἀνθρωπίνης συναναστροφῆς ἀπεληλασμένα. σὺ οὖν ἄνθρωπος ὢν οὐδὲ ζῷον εἶναι θέλεις τῶν ἀνθρώποις συντρόφων, ἀλλὰ σκώληξ μᾶλλον ἢ ἀράχνιον; οὐ λούσῃ πού ποτε ὡς θέλεις, οὐκ ἀποπλυνεῖς σεαυτόν, οὐχ ἥξεις καθαρός, ἵνα σοι χαίρωσιν οἱ συνόντες; ἀλλὰ καὶ εἰς τὰ ἱερὰ ἡμῖν συνέρχῃ τοιοῦτος, ὅπου πτῦσαι οὐ νενόμισται οὐδʼ ἀπομύξασθαι, ὅλος ὢν πτύσμα καὶ μύξα; τί οὖν; καλλωπίζεσθαί τις ἀξιοῖ; μὴ γένοιτο, εἰ μὴ ἐκεῖνο ὃ πεφύκαμεν, τὸν λόγον, τὰ δόγματα, τὰς ἐνεργείας, τὸ δὲ σῶμα μέχρι τοῦ καθαρίου, μέχρι τοῦ μὴ προσκόπτειν. ἀλλʼ ἂν ἀκούσῃς, ὅτι οὐ δεῖ φορεῖν κόκκινα, ἀπελθὼν κόπρωσόν σου τὸν τρίβωνα ἢ κατάρρηξον. — ἀλλὰ πόθεν ἔχω καλὸν τρίβωνα; — ἄνθρωπε, ὕδωρ ἔχεις, πλῦνον αὐτόν. ἰδοὺ νέος ἀξιέραστος, ἰδοὺ πρεσβύτης ἄξιος τοῦ ἐρᾶν καὶ ἀντερᾶσθαι, ᾧ τις υἱον αὑτοῦ παραδῷ μὴ γένοιτο. πᾶσα ἐκτροπὴ ἀπό τινος ἀνθρωπικοῦ γίνεται, αὕτη ἐγγύς ἐστι τῷ μὴ ἀνθρωπικὴ εἶναι.
english: Some raise a dispute as to whether the social instinct is included in the nature of man; yet these very same people would not, I think, dispute that cleanliness is certainly included in it, and that by this, if by nothing else, man is distinguished from the other animals. Accordingly, when we see any other animal cleaning itself, we are accustomed to speak with wonder and say that it is acting like a human being. On the other hand, if one condemns an animal for being dirty, we say instantly that it is, after all, not a human. Thus we suppose there is something superior about man which we first receive from the gods. For since the gods are by nature pure and uncorrupted, in so far as men have approached them by virtue of reason, they are to that extent naturally deeply attached to purity and cleanliness. But since it is impossible for their nature to be entirely pure, composed as it is of such corruptible stuff, reason is given to them to endeavor to make this material as clean as possible. The first and highest purity is that which is in the soul; and the same applies to impurity. Now, you could not find the impurity of the soul in a physical sense, as you would in the body; but as for the soul, what else could you find in it other than that which makes it filthy regarding its own functions? And the functions of the soul are to exercise impulse and repulsion, desire and aversion, preparation, design, and assent. What is it, then, that makes the soul filthy and unclean in these operations? It is nothing else but its own wicked judgments. Consequently, the impurity of the soul consists of bad opinions, and purification is the implantation of the right kind of opinions. And the soul is pure which has the right kind of opinions; for this soul alone is free from confusion and pollution in its own functions. Now one ought to endure to do something similar, as far as possible, for the body as well. It was impossible for the mucus of the nose not to flow so long as man has such a mixture of elements in his body; for this reason, Nature made hands and the nostrils themselves as channels to carry off the humors. If, then, a man sucks them up, I say that he is not performing the act of a human being. It was impossible for the feet not to be covered with mud and meant to be soiled when passing through such terrain; for this reason Nature prepared water and hands. It was impossible that some filth should not remain on the teeth after eating; for this reason, she says, wash your teeth. It was impossible that from sweat and the pressing of clothes, something dirty and requiring cleansing should not remain upon the body; for this reason we have water, oil, hands, towels, scrapers, soda, and all other such equipment to clean it. 'No,' you say. What? A smith acts as a smith—why? In order, I say to you, that you may act as a human being; and secondly, that you may not annoy those whom you meet. But you do something similar here to the smith who neglects his trade, and you do not perceive it. You think yourself worthy of smelling bad? Very well, be worthy of it! But do you think you are worthy to make those who sit by you smell it too? And those who recline at table with you? And those who kiss you? Go off into a desert somewhere, for that is what you are worthy of, and live there alone smelling of yourself. For it is only right that you alone should enjoy your own impurity. But when you are in a city, to behave so inconsiderately and foolishly, to whom do you think it appears good? If Nature had entrusted a horse to you, would you have overlooked it and left it untended? And now, think that your own body has been entrusted to you like a horse; wash it, wipe it off, make it so that no one will turn away from you, nor run away from you. But who does not turn away from a dirty man, one who smells, one who is foul-complexioned, more than from one who is bespattered with muck? The smell of the latter is external and accidental, but the smell of the former comes from lack of care and is from within, as if from a rotting thing. 'But Socrates rarely washed.' Yes, but his body was radiant; it was so gracious and agreeable that the most beautiful and noble men fell in love with him and desired to recline with him rather than with those who were physically most attractive. He had the right to neither wash nor bathe if he so pleased; yet even his 'rarely' had its effect. If you do not wish to wash with hot water, wash with cold. 'But Aristophanes says...' I tell you, all who have written about Socrates bear witness to exactly the opposite: that he was pleasant not only to hear but also to see. And they write the same regarding Diogenes. For one ought not to scare away the multitude from philosophy by the appearance of the body, but as in other things, a philosopher should show himself cheerful and unperturbed, so also in the body. 'See, men, that I have nothing, that I need nothing; see how, though I am homeless and stateless and an exile, if it so happens, and without a hearth, I live a more unperturbed and robust life than all the nobles and the rich. But look at my poor body, too, and see that it is not maltreated by my austere way of life.' But if one says this to me while wearing the face and figure of a condemned criminal, what god will persuade me to approach philosophy, which makes men like that? Heaven forbid! I would not do it, even if I were going to become a wise man. I, for my part, by the gods, would rather have the young man who is just beginning to be moved by philosophy come to me with his hair curled, than come with it shaggy and dirty. For in the former there is seen some faint notion of beauty and a desire for what is becoming; where he supposes it to be, there he applies his effort. It remains only to point it out to him and say: 'Young man, you are seeking the beautiful, and you do well. Know, then, that it grows in that part of you where you have your reason; seek it there where your impulses are, and your repulsions, where your desires and aversions are. For this implies a special prerogative which you have in yourself; but your poor body is by nature only clay. Why do you labor over it to no purpose? If for nothing else, you will learn by time that it is nothing.' But if a man comes to me all befouled, dirty, with a mustache down to his knees, what have I to say to him? By what resemblance can I lead him on? For what has he ever busied himself with that resembles the beautiful, so that I may change his direction and say, 'Beauty is not here, but there'? Do you want me to tell him, 'Beauty consists not in being befouled, but in reason'? For does he even have any desire for beauty? He shows signs of precisely the contrary. Therefore, the arguments of Xenocrates took hold of Polemo because he was a young man who loved beauty; for he entered having within him the sparks of a zeal for the beautiful, though he was looking for it in the wrong place. Nature has not made even the animals that live with men dirty. Does a horse wallow in the mire? Or a well-bred dog? No, but the hog does, and satisfy geese, and worms, and spiders—creatures that are banished furthest from human society. Will you, then, being a man, choose not to be even one of the animals that live with men, but rather a worm or a spider? Will you not wash yourself somewhere, as best you can? Will you not wash your clothes? Will you not come clean, so that those who are with you may take pleasure in you? But do you come even into the temples with us in such a state, where it is not lawful to spit or blow the nose, being yourself nothing but spittle and mucus? What then? Does anyone require you to beautify yourself? Heaven forbid! Except in that which is our true nature—the reason, the judgments, the actions; but as for the body, only so far as to be clean, so far as not to give offense. But if you are told that you must not wear scarlet, you go off and daub your cloak with muck, or tear it to pieces. 'But where can I get a fine cloak?' Man, you have water; wash it! Here is a young man worthy of being loved; here is an old man worthy of loving and being loved in return, one to whom a man would entrust his son, to be instructed by him. But as you are, who would approach you? Heaven forbid! Every deviation comes from something human; but this deviation of yours is close to being not human at all.
notes: In this lecture, Epictetus establishes the hierarchy of purity necessary for the Stoic life. The primary focus is the 'Inner Citadel': the purity of the soul (psychē), which is defined as the possession of correct judgments (dogmata) and the absence of vice. A dirty soul is one cluttered with false evaluations of external things. However, Epictetus strictly warns against the error of the 'False Cynic'—the student who mistakes philosophical simplicity for performative squalor. He argues that cleanliness (kathariotēs) is a natural, distinctively human trait mandated by our social nature (koinōnikon). Just as we care for a horse, we must care for the body as a tool given by Nature. To be physically repulsive is an act of arrogance and anti-social behavior, as it forces others to shun you, thereby cutting off the very social bonds a Stoic is meant to preserve. One cannot teach philosophy if one's appearance drives the student away. Therefore, basic hygiene is a duty to the community and a sign of respect for the divine gift of the human form.

greek: περὶ προσοχῆς. ὅταν ἀφῇς πρὸς ὀλίγον τὴν προσοχήν, μὴ τοῦτο φαντάζου, ὅτι, ὁπόταν θέλῃς, ἀναλήψῃ αὐτήν, ἀλλʼ ἐκεῖνο πρόχειρον ἔστω σοι, ὅτι παρὰ τὸ σήμερον ἁμαρτηθὲν εἰς τἆλλα χεῖρον ἀνάγκη σοι τὰ πράγματα ἔχειν. πρῶτον μὲν γὰρ τὸ πάντων χαλεπώτατον ἔθος τοῦ μὴ προσέχειν ἐγγίνεται, εἶτα ἔθος τοῦ ἀναβάλλεσθαι τὴν προσοχήν· ἀ ι εἰ μὲν οὖν λυσιτελὴς ἡ ὑπέρθεσίς ἐστιν, ἡ παντελὴς ἀπόστασις αὐτῆς ἐστι λυσιτελεστέρα· εἰ δʼ οὐ λυσιτελεῖ, τί οὐχὶ διηνεκῆ τὴν προσοχὴν φυλάσσεις; σήμερον παῖξαι θέλω. ᾆσαι. καὶ τί ἄλλο τῶν ἐν τῷ βίῳ κρεῖσσον ὑπὸ τῶν μὴ προσεχόντων γίνεται; ὁ τέκτων μὴ προσέχων ὁ κυβερνήτης μὴ προσέχων οὐκ αἰσθάνῃ, ὅτι, ἐπειδὰν ἀφῇς τὴν γνώμην, οὐκ ἔτι ἐπὶ σοί ἐστιν ἀνακαλέσασθαι αὐτήν, οὐκ ἐπὶ τὸ εὔσχημον, οὐκ ἐπὶ τὸ αἰδῆμον, οὐκ ἐπὶ τὸ κατεσταλμένον; ἀλλὰ πᾶν τὸ ἐπελθὸν ποιεῖς, ταῖς προθυμίαις ἐπακολουθεῖς. τίσιν οὖν δεῖ με προσέχειν;— πρῶτον μὲν ἐκείνοις τοῖς καθολικοῖς καὶ ἐκεῖνα πρόχειρα ἔχειν καὶ χωρὶς ἐκείνων μὴ καθεύδειν, μὴ ἀνίστασθαι, μὴ πίνειν, μὴ ἐσθίειν, μὴ συμβάλλειν ἀνθρώποις· ὅτι προαιρέσεως ἀλλοτρίας κύριος οὐδείς, ἐν ταύτῃ δὲ μόνῃ τἀγαθὸν καὶ κακόν. οὐδεὶς οὖν κύριος οὔτʼ ἀγαθόν μοι περιποιῆσαι οὔτε κακῷ με περιβαλεῖν, ἀλλʼ ἐγὼ αὐτὸς ἐμαυτοῦ κατὰ ταῦτα ἐξουσίαν ἔχω μόνος. ὅταν οὖν ταῦτα ἀσφαλῆ μοι ᾖ, τί ἔχω περὶ τὰ ἐκτὸς ταράσσεσθαι; ποῖος τύραννος φοβερός, ποία νόσος, ποία πενία, ποῖον πρόσκρουσμα; — ἀλλʼ οὐκ ἤρεσα τῷ δεῖνι. — μὴ οὖν ἐκεῖνος ἐμόν ἐστιν ἔργον, μή τι ἐμὸν κρίμα; — οὔ. — τί οὖν ἔτι μοι μέλει; — ἀλλὰ δοκεῖ τις εἶναι. — ὄψεται αὐτὸς καὶ οἷς δοκεῖ, ἐγὼ δʼ ἔχω, τίνι με δεῖ ἀρέσκειν, τίνι ὑποτετάχθαι, τίνι πείθεσθαι· τῷ θεῷ καὶ μετʼ ἐκεῖνον τί τὸ αἴτιον ταύτης τῆς ταραχῆς; οὐδὲν ἄλλο ἢ ὅτι ἐν τούτῳ τῷ τόπῳ ἀγύμναστός εἰμι. ἐπεί τοι πᾶσα ἐπιστήμη καταφρονητική ἐστι τῆς ἀγνοίας καὶ τῶν ἀγνοούντων καὶ οὐ μόνον αἱ ἐπιστῆμαι, ἀλλὰ καὶ αἱ τέχναι. φέρε ὃν θέλεις σκυτέα καὶ τῶν πολλῶν καταγελᾷ περὶ τὸ αὑτοῦ ἔργον· φέρε ὃν θέλεις τέκτονα. πρῶτον μὲν οὖν ταῦτα ἔχειν πρόχειρα καὶ μηδὲν δίχα τούτων ποιεῖν, ἀλλὰ τετάσθαι τὴν ψυχὴν ἐπὶ τοῦτον τὸν σκοπόν, μηδὲν τῶν ἔξω διώκειν, μηδὲν τῶν ἀλλοτρίων, ἀλλʼ ὡς διέταξεν ὁ δυνάμενος, τὰ προαιρετικὰ ἐξ ἅπαντος, τὰ δʼ ἄλλα ὡς ἂν διδῶται. ἐπὶ τούτοις δὲ μεμνῆσθαι, τίνες ἐσμὲν καὶ τί ἡμῖν ὄνομα, καὶ πρὸς τὰς δυνάμεις τῶν σχέσεων πειρᾶσθαι τὰ καθήκοντα ἀπευθύνειν· τίς καιρὸς ᾠδῆς, τίς καιρὸς παιδ ε οὐκ ἔξωθέν ποθεν, ἀλλʼ ἐξ αὐτῆς τῆς ἐνεργείας. τί οὖν; δυνατὸν ἀναμάρτητον ἤδη εἶναι; ἀμήχανον, ἀλλʼ ἐκεῖνο δυνατὸν πρὸς τὸ μὴ ἁμαρτάνειν τετάσθαι διηνεκῶς. ἀγαπητὸν γάρ, εἰ μηδέποτʼ ἀνιέντες ταύτην τὴν προσοχὴν ὀλίγων γε ἁμαρτημάτων ἐκτὸς ἐσόμεθα. νῦν δʼ ὅταν εἴπῃς ἀπαύριον προσέξω, σήμερον ἔσομαι ἀναίσχυντος, ἄκαιρος, ταπεινός· ἐπʼ ἄλλοις ἔσται τὸ λυπεῖν με· ὀργισθήσομαι σήμερον, φθονήσω. βλέπε, ὅσα κακὰ σεαυτῷ ἐπιτρέπεις. ἀλλʼ εἴ σοι αὔριον καλῶς ἔχει, πόσῳ κρεῖττον σήμερον· εἰ αὔριον συμφέρει, πολὺ μᾶλλον σήμερον, ἵνα καὶ αὔριον δυνηθῇς καὶ μὴ πάλιν ἀναβάλῃ εἰς τρίτην.
english: On Attention. When you relax your attention for a short while, do not imagine that you will recover it whenever you please. Instead, keep this thought ready at hand: that because of today's error, your affairs must necessarily be in a worse condition henceforth. First, the habit of inattention—the hardest of all to break—installs itself, followed by the habit of deferring attention. If procrastination is beneficial, then total abandonment is even more so; but if it is not beneficial, why do you not maintain your attention continuously? 'I want to play today,' you say. Then play! 'I want to sing.' Then sing! But is anything in life done better by those who are not paying attention? Does the carpenter do his work better by being inattentive? Does the helmsman steer better by being inattentive? Do you not realize that once you let your mind loose, it is no longer in your power to recall it to propriety, to modesty, or to moderation? Instead, you do whatever comes into your head and follow your impulses. 'To what, then, must I pay attention?' First, to those universal principles which you must have always at hand: without them do not sleep, do not rise, do not drink, do not eat, do not interact with people. Realize that no one is master of another's moral choice, and that in this alone lie good and evil. No one, therefore, has the power to secure good for me, nor to involve me in evil; I alone have authority over myself in these matters. When, therefore, I am secure in these points, why am I still troubled about external things? What tyrant is to be feared, what disease, what poverty, what stumbling block? 'But I did not please so-and-so.' Is he my concern? Is he my judgment? No. 'Why, then, do I care?' 'But he seems to be someone of importance.' Let him look to that, and those who think so. But I have One whom I must please, to whom I must be subject, whom I must obey: God. And after Him, what is the cause of my disturbance? Nothing else than that in this matter I am untrained. Is it possible to be free from fault right now? It is impossible. But this is possible: to be constantly stretched toward not committing faults. For we must be content if, by never relaxing this attention, we escape at least a few errors. But now, when you say, 'I will pay attention tomorrow,' know that you are essentially saying, 'Today I will be shameless, untimely, and base; it shall be in the power of others to grieve me; today I will be angry and envious.' See how many evils you permit yourself! If it is good for you to attend tomorrow, how much better is it today? If it is profitable tomorrow, it is much more so today, so that you may be able to do so tomorrow as well, and not put it off again to the third day.
notes: This discourse defines 'Prosochē' (attention/mindfulness), the fundamental spiritual attitude of the practicing Stoic. It is a state of continuous, vigilant tension ('tonos') of the mind. Epictetus warns that character is cumulative; a moment of carelessness is not an isolated event but the seed of a habit that degrades the will. The specific object of this attention is not obsession with trivial details, but the constant application of the 'Universal Principles'—specifically the Dichotomy of Control (distinguishing between one's own moral choice and external events). Epictetus offers a pragmatic rejection of perfectionism: the goal is not to be instantly sinless (which is impossible for the non-Sage), but to maintain the constant 'stretch' or effort to avoid error. Finally, he attacks procrastination, arguing that delaying the practice of virtue is an active decision to remain vicious and vulnerable to suffering today.
